equal to the price offered to each other holder of such series of Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption—General.”

The Notes will be general senior secured obligations of the Issuer and will (i) rank pari passu in right of payment with all existing and future senior indebtedness of the Issuer, including
indebtedness outstanding under the Senior Facilities, (ii) rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s existing and future indebtedness that is expressly subordinated in right of
payment to the Notes, (iii) be effectively subordinated to all of the Issuer’s existing and future indebtedness that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes to the extent of
the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness and (iv) be structurally subordinated to any existing and future debt of the Issuer’s existing and future subsidiaries that do not
guarantee the Notes, including their obligations to trade creditors. The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis (i) on the Issue Date, by the Issue Date Guarantor, which is a
guarantor under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, and (ii) within 60 days from the Issue Date, by the Post-Closing Date Guarantors, all of which are guarantors under the
Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, provided that such guarantees are in all cases subject to the Agreed Security Principles and to the limitations described in “Certain Insolvency
_Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests.” Each of the Guarantees of the Notes will (i) be general senior secured_
obligations of the Guarantors, (ii) rank pari passu in right of payment with all such Guarantors’ existing and future senior indebtedness that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment
to the Notes and any guarantees thereof, including indebtedness outstanding under the Senior Facilities and any guarantees thereof, (iii) rank senior in right of payment to all of such
Guarantor’s existing and future indebtedness that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes and any guarantees thereof and (iv) be effectively subordinated to all of such
Guarantor’s existing and future indebtedness that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness.

**Overview**

We are the world’s leading independent producer and distributor of content based on revenues for the
year ended December 31, 2022. We are also the world’s leading independent producer and distributor
of content in terms of hours of content as of June 30, 2023. We develop, produce and distribute
television formats and programs and digital content for a wide range of customers. We operate over
130 production companies across 21 countries and have a multi-genre catalogue boasting over
172,000 hours of content. We have produced successful, and at times, long-running scripted and nonscripted formats and programs, such as _Survivor, Temptation Island, Peaky Blinders, Big Brother,_
_MasterChef, Rogue Heroes, Hunted, Black Mirror, LEGO Masters, Deal or No Deal, Grantchester,_
_Don’t Forget The Lyrics!, Marie Antoinette, Fort Boyard, Versailles, Mr. Bean and_ _Good Karma_
_Hospital. Our broad brand portfolio and large creative platform position us to continue to nurture and_
drive new formats for broadcasters and digital platforms.

We generate revenues through (i) the production of formats and programs; (ii) the distribution of
formats and programs for which we hold and/or control intellectual property rights and are entitled to
revenues generated by such formats and programs and (iii) commercial activities related to our brands
and programs, such as merchandising, sponsorship, licensing, digital partnerships, music and live
events. We produce both scripted and non-scripted content across all genres, including reality,
entertainment and talk shows, game shows, factual entertainment, documentary, drama, animation (or
kids) and comedy. Non-scripted content includes titles that do not follow a written storyline (for
example, entertainment, game shows or reality) and generated the majority of our revenues for the
year ended December 31, 2022, while scripted content includes programs that follow a written
scenario, which mainly consists of drama and comedy.

We own intellectual property rights to a broad and diversified portfolio of formats and programs, and
we generated the majority of our production revenues from our owned intellectual property for the
year ended December 31, 2022. The programs we own and/or control were distributed and licensed,
through our subsidiary, Banijay Rights Limited, to approximately 1,050 licensees, including linear
broadcasters and digital platforms worldwide, and we sold our products into 249 territories, in each
case for the year ended December 31, 2022. We retain (either through full ownership or control
pursuant to long-term and exclusive distribution contracts with third-party producers) the intellectual
property rights to most of our formats and programs. Such intellectual property rights are assets that
we generally distribute internationally and from which we seek to generate secondary revenues, such
as licensing of exploitation rights to broadcasters and digital platforms and sales of finished tapes and
branded content, in each case to supplement our initial production revenues.

We employ creative talents across all territories in which we operate in order to develop original
formats and produce original television programs based on our analysis of trends in the industry and
the demands of our customers. Thanks to our significant scale and the scope of our business, we have
access to a wide variety of industry-leading talents worldwide and high-quality creative content. For
the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we generated €3,242 million of revenues, of which €2,676
million (or 83% of total revenues) were production revenues, €413 million (or 12% of total revenues)


-----

were distribution revenues and €153 million (or 5% of total revenues) were secondary revenues. For
the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, our Run-Rate Revenues was €3,609 million, our Run-Rate
Adjusted EBITDA was €544 million and our Adjusted Free Cash Flow was €347 million.

**Our Strengths**

We believe that the following strengths differentiate us from our competitors and provide us with
competitive advantages in the markets in which we operate:

**_World’s Leading Independent Content Producer and Distributor_**

We are the world’s leading independent producer and distributor of content based on revenues for the
year ended December 31, 2022, as well as catalogue depth in the independent production sector, with
an unmatched library of over 172,000 hours of content as of June 30, 2023. The following graphic
shows the revenues and catalogue depth of the producers that we consider to be our main competitors:

______________

(1) Represents data as of December 31, 2022 for Banijay, and latest available market data for other players.

(2) Excludes major U.S. studios such as Disney and Warner Brothers, as well as independent players such as MGM and Lionsgate.

While the global content spend market represented approximately $238 billion as of December 31,
2022, according to Ampere, the top players mentioned in the graphic above represented
approximately 8% of that market, reflecting a long tail-end of smaller players in the sector and the
overall fragmented nature of the industry. Within this largely fragmented content production
landscape, we are well positioned as a global leader benefitting from an international, independent
studio and a largely de-risked business model, underpinned by a cost-plus pricing base of our
productions wherein customers finance the entire production costs for most non-scripted shows. The
following graphic shows the characteristics of the main types of players in the global content spend
market:


-----

Our leading position as the largest international independent studio positions us favorably in
comparison with other business models within the content production landscape. This landscape
mainly comprises (i) in-house production departments of SVOD operators and broadcasters (e.g.
Netflix and Apple), which have less independence, (ii) major U.S. studios (e.g. Comcast, Disney,
Lionsgate, Paramount and Sony), which operate a vertical, riskier business model, (iii) smaller
independent players, which tend to have niche, sub-scale operations lacking critical size, in addition to
(iv) independent studios with scale such as the Group. Our favorable positioning within this
competitive landscape ensures that we benefit from a largely de-risked business model as well as from
scale and independence, allowing us to optimally roll our existing successful content and new
upcoming releases across geographies, formats and distribution partners.

**_Attractive Market with Growing Demand for Content Driven by SVOD Platforms_**

We continue to operate in a global and attractive market characterized by stable growth, which has
proven to be resilient, including throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. Over the last ten years, global
content spend has almost doubled in absolute terms, as demonstrated by the following graphic:

The growth in global content spend is expected to continue to be driven largely by the surging
demand from SVOD platforms, which is expected to grow by more than 21% per year from 2020 to
2025, as demonstrated by the following graphic:


-----

In addition, SVOD platforms have recently increased their exposure to non-scripted content, with the
number of non-scripted shows on SVOD platforms in the United States more than tripling over the
last three years from 125 shows in 2019 to 397 shows in 2022. We believe that we are well positioned
to benefit from this trend thanks to our strong non-scripted production capabilities, which allow us to
produce formats in a hub model for SVOD in several countries. Broadcaster demand has also
remained resilient, despite increasing pressures on advertising revenues.

**_Platform Agnostic and Highly Diversified Revenue Base Across Geographies, Genres, Customers_**
**_and Shows_**

We are a global producer and distributor of content, generating revenues in 21 countries, including 14
countries in Europe (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, the Nordic Countries, Poland,
Portugal, Spain, Switzerland and the United Kingdom), three countries in the Americas (Brazil,
Mexico and the United States), three countries in the Asia Pacific region (Australia, India and New
Zealand) and one country in the rest of the world (Israel). For the twelve months ended June 2023,
48% of our revenues were generated in Europe, 31% in the Americas and 21% in the rest of the
world. Thanks to our broad portfolio of successful formats and programs that can be adapted to a
variety of audiences across multiple geographies, we believe we are well-positioned to maintain and
grow our share in our current markets. Our distribution business enables us to license our portfolio of
formats and programs around the world, including to customers located in markets in which we do not
currently maintain production operations. Notably, our catalogue of non-scripted content (including
our “super brands”) is available in a broad range of non-English languages, allowing us to capitalize
on the growth of streaming platforms outside of the U.S. and to reach audiences globally.

We work with a broad network of customers and partners, including broadcasters, television channels,
producers and digital platforms active in the markets in which we operate, as well as with licensees,
retailers of consumer products and commercial partners from around the world. Our main production
customers include broadcasters such as France Télévisions, TF1 Group, ITV, the BBC, Channel 4
Television, FOX, CBS, Bravo, Antena 3, TVE, Channel 5, RTL Group, TV2 Denmark, NENT, DR
Denmark, TV4 Sweden, SKY, Mediaset, Rai Uno, Canal Plus Group, ABC Network, NBC,
Discovery and MTV. We are also platform agnostic, which allows us to nurture relationships with
numerous digital platforms, including SVOD providers (such as Netflix, Amazon Prime Video,
Disney+, Discovery+, HBO Max, Paramount+ and Peacock) and AVOD platforms (such as Globo,
Pluto and Freevee). For the year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 18% of our total revenues
were generated from OTT players, an increase of approximately 10% compared to the year ended
December 31, 2020. For the year ended December 31, 2022, our eight biggest customers contributed
to 43% of our total production revenues, with none of our customers individually contributing to more
than 12% of our total revenues during the same period. In addition, we often have multiple contracts,
which address multiple formats and geographies, with individual customers. Similarly, our top 15
shows collectively contributed to 17% of our production revenues for the year ended December 31,
2022, with none of our shows individually contributing to more than 2% of our production revenues
during the same period. The following graphics show, for the year ended December 31, 2022, our
production revenues (i) by top customers and (ii) by top shows:

**_Proven Ability to Develop Long-Lasting Worldwide Brands Generating Primary and Secondary_**
**_Revenues_**

We have a proven track record of producing and distributing long-lasting and travelling content (i.e.,
formatted content which can be adapted by our companies worldwide), which have become durable
“super brands”. We define such “super brands” as premium unscripted formats with robust returning
appeal across at least ten different markets with significant production budgets, and which are
profitable in the context of a large-scale distribution. We are the content producer that has adapted the
most unscripted formats globally, such as Deal or No Deal (launched in 2002, and adapted in over 80
territories), Big Brother (launched in 1999, and adapted in over 70 territories), MasterChef (launched
in 1990, and adapted in over 60 territories) and Minute to Win It (launched in 2010, and adapted in
over 50 territories). We have increasingly focused on formats that, once produced for one market, can
be licensed internationally to reach customers in other markets. For the year ended December 31,
2022, our top travelling formats were MasterChef (active in 39 territories), Big Brother (active in 33
territories), _Survivor (active in 21 territories) and_ _LEGO Masters (active in 15 territories). The_
following table shows a breakdown of some of our most successful long-lasting and travelling
programs and formats by (i) genre, (ii) number of active years since launch, (iii) country of origin, (iv)
total number of territories since launch (which represents the number of format adaptations for nonscripted shows and licensing of finished tapes for scripted shows) and (v) customers:

Our diversified portfolio of long-standing and travelling formats and programs is supported by “360degree” monetization of our formats and programs. This approach allows us to monetize our content
from the production of new formats and programs to be sold to broadcasters and digital platforms, to
the licensing of existing formats to third parties and the sale of programs to generate distribution
revenues and leverage our strong brands to create secondary revenues through commercial activities
such as merchandising, sponsorship, digital partnerships, music and live events. The following
graphic shows our revenues by business type (production, distribution and other, excluding

with exclusivity and control on the worldwide production and distribution of our owned formats and
programs, as well as the further potential to generate secondary revenues from the programs and
formats for which we own intellectual property rights. In addition, our distribution and secondary
revenues businesses generate high margins, providing royalties to production companies and owners

**_Strong Track Record of Successfully Integrating Value Accretive Acquisitions_**

We have a history of successfully pursuing various selective and value-enhancing strategic
acquisitions, business combinations and joint ventures intended to complement and/or expand our
business. We regularly pursue value-accretive bolt-on acquisitions to acquire production companies
and/or intellectual property rights in the markets where we are present. Thanks to these acquisitions,
we are able to expand into new markets or genres in a particular market, access new talent, acquire
intellectual property rights of formats and programs developed by such companies and benefit from
the expertise of their creative talents or producers. Some of our most recent acquisitions and
significant investments include Beyond in Australia in December 2022, A Fábrica in Brazil in March
2023, Twenty Two Productions in the Netherlands in March 2023, as well as our joint venture with
LaLiga in Spain in June 2023. Further, in June 2023, we agreed to acquire a controlling stake in
Balich, an Italian live entertainment business in charge of creating, producing and delivering live
shows and experiences that engage live audiences worldwide, active in 20 countries, in line with our
strategy to expand our live event activities. The following timeline shows our bolt-on acquisitions
made during the development of our business:

We also have a proven track record of successfully integrating large groups and implementing
synergies within a short period of time following transformative acquisitions. For example, in 2020,
the completion of the Endemol Shine Acquisition allowed us to become the leading independent
player in Europe with the highest number of scripted content launches in 2022, thereby gaining the
scale necessary to address the strong appetite in our industry for globally distributed brands. Thanks
to the successful integration of Endemol Shine into the Group, we benefitted from structural
simplification, commercial synergies, IT integration, footprint optimization and rationalization of
third-party service providers, and realized cost synergies of approximately €67 million within a period
of 18 months, exceeding the originally projected cost synergies of approximately €60 million within
24 months. Our net leverage ratio as of September 30, 2019, after giving effect to the Endemol Shine
Acquisition, the financing arrangements entered in connection therewith and the use of proceeds
therefrom, was 5.2x. We have since successfully reduced our total net leverage and are on track to
further reduce it (exclusive of acquisitions that may be consummated (other than the Balich
Acquisition), in the medium term).

We are also focused on pursuing strategic joint ventures, which allow us to be involved in the early
stages of potential successes and, in the long term, to secure the possibility of acquiring a controlling
interest in the underlying company for a price based on a pre-existing formula that takes into account
our investment and support. Since 2018, we have also established several joint ventures in the United
Kingdom and the United States, the most active markets for international scripted shows, including
recent investments in Rabbit Track, Conker and Immovable in the United Kingdom. We also have
successful joint ventures in Mexico, such as Endemol Shine Boomdog, which was formed in 2018 to
capitalize on the growing opportunities in the Mexican and U.S Spanish-language markets.


-----

Thanks to our successful acquisition track-record, we have been able to grow our platform globally,
positioning us well to serve an increasingly global customer base, including OTT players who can
deploy our formats into multiple geographies. We believe that in a fragmented and competitive
industry, our significant scale allows us to increase our leverage when negotiating with broadcasters
and SVOD platforms, diversify our portfolio by introducing new cross-selling opportunities, increase
our financial capacity to fund a large number of formats, offer more competitive production budgets
by leveraging on combined resources and attract and retain talent.

**_A Cash Generative and Resilient Business Model Supported by a Recurring Revenue Base, Strong_**
**_Financial Performance, Cash Flow Visibility and a Flexible Cost Structure_**

Our portfolio of long-standing “super brands,” such as Big Brother, MasterChef, Survivor and
Temptation Island, allows us to benefit from strong and long-term recurring revenues, with 43% of
our production revenues for the year ended December 31, 2022 derived from content that has been
running for at least five consecutive seasons, 30% from content that has been running for two to five
consecutive seasons, and only 28% from new launches. Certain of our production companies, such as
Banijay Production Media, Adventure Line Productions and Bunim/Murray Productions have
produced television content for more than 20 years, and we benefit from their long-standing
relationships with broadcasters and other customers. We believe that our ability to propose original
formats with a cost-efficient production process has increased customer loyalty. We have further
expanded our customer base and captured business opportunities associated with the rise of SVOD
providers by developing relationships with Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, Disney+, Discovery+,
HBO Max, Paramount+ and Peacock.

Over the last three years, we have achieved significant Adjusted EBITDA improvement, which has
grown from €262 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €482 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022. Following our recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, our Adjusted EBITDA
margin levels normalized to 15% for the year ended December 31, 2022, demonstrating resilience
against inflation thanks to our cost-plus pricing-based business model, which allows us to pass on a
significant amount of incremental costs to our customers. This is higher than the average EBITDA
margin over the last three years of the producers that we consider to be our main competitors. We
have also reduced our leverage and maintained strong cash generation, with Adjusted Free Cash Flow
ranging from €256 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €349 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022. Our average cash conversion ratio for the same period was 83.2%, due in 2020 to
the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our production, tax and social security payments, and in
2021 to a favorable working capital cut-off effect at the end of the year and the normalization of our
production activities after the COVID-19 pandemic.We intend to continue to implement our
acquisition schemes based on earn-outs and put options in order to limit our cash interest expense.

We believe we have a largely de-risked business model. Our revenue benefits from the longevity of
our returning formats, such as Survivor, Big Brother, _MasterChef and Deal or No Deal. The majority_
of our formats air for more than one season, which generates long-term revenue streams and
significant visibility into our operating performance as we secure budgeted revenues through contracts
signed early in the production process, and some of our returning formats benefit from multi-season
deals with broadcasters and digital platforms. These formats continue to be successful, for instance
with the 24[th] season of _Big Brother being viewed for approximately 8.3 billion minutes across all_
platforms in two months, with particular success in the U.S., and Survivor airing 25 series across 24
territories. For the year ended December 31, 2022, 28% and 73% of the Group’s production revenues
were generated by new and returning programs, respectively (of which 43% had been running for at
least five consecutive seasons, and 30% for two to five consecutive seasons). As of June 30, 2023, we
had already secured at least 84% of our estimated revenues for the year ending December 31, 2023.
Our business model is also supported by a stable level of content spend, which has been resilient
during economic downturns, as compared to advertisement spend. We have retained our competitive
advantage despite increasing pressures on advertising revenues, thanks to our focus on less expensive
non-scripted content, performing “super brands” that are pillars of traditional broadcasters and costefficient production plans.


-----

We only commence the production for a program once a broadcaster or digital platform has agreed to
pay for the production and acquisition of the rights for such program, and the production costs have
been fully funded. We use the services of a significant number of freelance production artists and
technicians, depending on the level of television production activity in which we are engaged. Such
freelancers allow us to benefit from a flexible cost structure pursuant to which we can adjust our cost
base to the seasonality of production activity throughout the year. We estimate that approximately
80% of our cost structure is flexible. In addition, we attract, retain and incentivize talents via longterm incentive plans which are generally contingent and calculated based on the performance of the
relevant format over a specified time period. Therefore, our production costs and a significant share of
our staff costs are based on our performance and activity levels and are variable in nature.

We operate an asset-light model with limited ongoing capital expenditure requirements (representing
1.8% of revenues, including investments in intellectual property rights, for the year ended December
31, 2022), and low working capital requirements. Non-scripted programs are generally less capitalintensive and more profitable than scripted programs because they have shorter production cycles and
their budgeted production costs are covered in full before production begins. We believe that our mix
of scripted and non-scripted content is generally appropriate for our operations. In the event that we
seek to increase the proportion of our revenues generated by scripted programs, we do not anticipate
having to invest significantly as we expect that third-party financing sources will largely incur the
required upfront investment costs and that we will benefit from our existing catalogue’s distribution
revenues. In addition, we continuously promote financial discipline to maximize cash generation and
monitor our leverage.

**_Highly Experienced and Committed Management Team with Supportive Shareholders_**

The Group has a highly experienced and professional senior management team, consisting of
Stéphane Courbit, Chairman and founder of Banijay, Marco Bassetti, Chief Executive Officer, and
Cédric Brignon, Chief Financial Officer. Both Stéphane Courbit and Marco Bassetti have a successful
track record of television content production. Since 2007, Banijay has become a leading independent
producer of television programs based on revenues. Our management team has a proven track record
of delivering on their budget and has demonstrated strong M&A capabilities, successfully integrating
new businesses into the Group such as the Banijay Zodiak Merger (realizing cost synergies of
approximately €17 million within a period of 10 months) and the Endemol Shine Acquisition
(realizing cost synergies of approximately €67 million within a period of 18 months, exceeding the
originally projected cost synergies of approximately €60 million within 24 months). During the year
ended December 31, 2022, we successfully completed 15 bolt-on acquisition in ten different
countries. Unlike some of our competitors, the Group is led by industry experts who understand our
creative talents and local production managers. This common culture and vision between our
management team and our creative talents have allowed us to attract and retain successful managers,
employees and partners. Furthermore, we benefit from the full support of our shareholders, including
DeA and Vivendi, two groups with a history of investing in the distribution of content and
broadcasters. LOV Group and Vivendi are industry experts who understand the television production
and distribution business and are focused on developing original content. While most of the largest
television content producers in the world are affiliated with an entertainment group or a distribution
network, we remain independent, which enables us to serve customers without the limitations faced
by controlled producers regarding, for example, the content, style and format of their production. Our
independence allows us to innovate, deliver original, differentiated programs, be platform agnostic
and work with and retain a large pool of creative talents. In addition, as a scaled independent
producer, we benefit from competitive advantages compared to the in-house departments of
broadcasters and U.S. studios in Europe, which favor European independent producers.

We believe we are positioned at the forefront of content production and distribution as a premier
home for the industry’s leading on- and off-screen talent, and pride ourselves upon our ability to
attract, grow and retain top creative talent, including creative talent, producers, screenwriters and
directors. We have a number of key initiatives in place in order to further promote workforce
retention. In connection with the acquisition of production companies in various jurisdictions, we


-----

typically enter into earn-out or put option agreements with certain managers and creative talents of
these companies in order to incentivize them to continue to work with us following the completion of
the relevant acquisition. Our management has also implemented a long-term incentive plan to ensure
the commitment of local management teams by rewarding key personnel based on their respective
value creation. In addition, our corporate organization is designed to foster creative freedom,
collaborative entrepreneurialism and commercial acumen. As a responsible employer, we are aware of
the rapid changes in lifestyles and ways of living of our employees, particularly following the
COVID-19 pandemic, and we actively seek to contribute to the improvement of our employees’
quality of life to maintain long, successful and trusting relationships. We have chosen to improve our
employee experience through the implementation of selective remote-working policies to help reduce
commuting stress, free up time and stay competitive in the talent war. We have also committed to
building diverse, supportive and collaborative teams through the development of our global diversity
& inclusion board and employee resource groups.

**Our Strategies**

We intend to further strengthen our business by focusing on the following key strategic objectives.

**_Continue to Create Premium International Content and Secure Intellectual Property Rights_**

Our goal is to continue to focus on high premium formats and programs that can travel to other
territories and be easily distributed globally to broadcasters and digital platforms looking for new
content, such as _Survivor,_ _Big Brother,_ _MasterChef and_ _Deal or No Deal. Through our dedicated_
distribution subsidiary, Banijay Rights Limited, we intend to leverage our know-how on successfully
selling or licensing our catalogue, including to customers in markets where we do not produce
content. We also intend to increase the size of our program portfolio to reach new customers in
emerging markets, such as India, where we believe there is great potential for growth in terms of
viewers and where a program based on the same format can be produced for different territories in
different languages, which we have capacity to produce thanks to our local production labels. For the
year ended December 31, 2022, we generated 12% of our total revenues from our distribution
business. Formats that have already been developed and produced, together with existing programs,
can be distributed with comparatively high margins.

We intend to apply our strategy of incentivizing local managing directors to develop adaptable
formats in-house with an international appeal that can generate distribution and other secondary
revenues, together with our proven format-sharing practices. Some of our most anticipated upcoming
releases include _Totally Spies! and_ _Nevsu. In addition, we plan to further develop our relationships_
with third-party producers to secure productions outside our footprint and distribution rights of
premium content through Banijay Rights Limited. We focus on sourcing partnerships and deals that
generate positive returns and making selective investments to secure intellectual property rights from
producers that we believe can deliver new long-running formats. We target premium scripted content
in the English language, which can be easily distributed internationally and is well-suited to the
catalogue of many OTT platforms, as well as formatted non-scripted content which can often be
adapted by our companies worldwide.

We believe that this strategy will allow us to capitalize on current market trends, with SVOD
platforms increasing their demand for non-scripted content, in addition to their traditional focus on
scripted content. We also plan to continue focusing on developing know-how in our different markets
in order to create traction for upcoming formats developed in another country.

**_Optimize Content and Catalogue Monetization on All Platforms Globally_**

In the United States, SVOD services have increased the value of our catalogue series and movies due
to increased viewership by consumers and the correlating demand and spending by digital platforms.
Although these investments are primarily made in the United States and in English-language content,
the European market is gaining an increasing amount of traction with U.S.-based streaming platforms,


-----

which are expanding globally. We also benefit from a supportive regulatory environment in Europe
which helps balancing bargaining powers when negotiating with SVOD platforms, hence allowing for
multiple monetization channels.

As a global independent producer with a proven track record of producing and distributing longlasting and travelling content (through local versions of some of the world’s biggest titles, as well as
original territorial content in local languages), we believe we are well-positioned to capitalize on these
trends and to efficiently monetize our content across all platforms through our “360-degree” strategy.
We intend to continue developing best-in-class internal format-sharing practices and, due to our size
and decentralized organizational structure, we believe we can tailor our formats and programs to our
target customers more easily than other large production groups, thereby efficiently monetizing our
content and catalogue. In addition, our distribution business enables us to license our portfolio
globally, including in markets in which we do not currently maintain production operations, and
generate revenues with high margins due to the relatively limited costs incurred in managing our
existing formats and programs.

We intend to increase our secondary revenues by better monetizing our large catalogue of over
172,000 hours of content. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we generated 5% of our revenues
from our commercial activity, including secondary revenues. We aim to increase secondary revenues
by taking advantage of in-program digital technologies and other features, and also developing
sponsorships with on-air partners to integrate product placement in our programs and to supplement
broadcasters’ production budgets. The rapidly growing AVOD market represents new secondary
window exploitation opportunities for our content, and we believe we have already positioned
ourselves as a leader in the FAST space to seize such opportunities, thanks to the operation of our
own FAST channels (including Horizons: Powered By Banijay) syndicated on platforms such as Pluto
or Freevee. We are also increasing our presence on social media platforms such as Meta and TikTok
in order to reach online audiences and further monetize our catalogue through digitalization.

In addition, we focus on developing branded content and partnerships with brands to establish content
supplier agreements with key global broadcasters. We try to retain ancillary rights when negotiating
with broadcasters to be able to develop merchandizing, branded events and experiences and off-air
licenses, and exploit the full value chain of our intellectual property rights. For example, we have
entered into a brand licensing arrangement for Peaky Blinders in connection with the development of
a freemium mobile strategy game. We are also able to monetize content with low development costs
through digital platforms with live-streaming capabilities, and through the development of games
based on intellectual property rights which we retain in connection with our formats.

We have leveraged our know-how with in-house talents by creating talent agencies which generate
secondary revenues, having followed the model of the talent management agency managed by
Brainpool. Notably, Banijay Talent operates as a French “influencer” marketing company that helps
brands grow with bespoke influencing strategies, and has generated significant follower growth for
its customer brands and developed key relationships with a large number of influencers from the
television, fashion, beauty, luxury, entertainment and sport sectors. We intend to further emulate the
commercial success of Banijay Talent across other countries where we operate to increase our
secondary revenues.

**_Continue to Attract and Retain the Best Talents_**

We rely on our management team to implement our growth strategies and our creative talents to
produce formats that address our customers’ needs. Attracting, cultivating and retaining talents has
been, and will remain, critical to our success. We plan to continue to attract and retain highly skilled
personnel, particularly for their creative talent. We intend to further strengthen our collaborative and
entrepreneurial culture by continuing to incentivize our local managers to foster the high flexibility,
independence and autonomy of each of our production companies. We also intend to continue to run
our long-term incentive plan to ensure the commitment of local management teams and focus on
further aligning our key personnel’s interests with the Group’s through a focus on value creation.


-----

Similarly, we plan to maintain our Group-wide bonus scheme to incentivize creative talents
responsible for the creation and development of successful formats that are adapted in our key
markets and have generated a certain production value for the Group. Talent attraction and retention is
also bolstered by our talent management systems, which allow us to anticipate departures and plan for
successions in the event of any departures.

Our proven track record of establishing successful joint ventures is also a key part of our talent
acquisition and retention strategy, as joint ventures appeal to talents who would like to maintain their
independence but are interested in a strong partnership with us. Talents of our joint venture partners
benefit from our broad creative network, access to financing, information, contacts and, most
importantly, our catalogue of formats, major brands and distribution capacity. In addition, they may
be able to sell us their remaining shareholding once the business has developed successfully because,
if a joint venture is successful, we may acquire the remaining share capital in the production company
on pre-agreed financial terms while retaining the talents who partnered with us.

**_Consolidate our Leadership Through Selective M&A to Further Strengthen our Position as an_**
**_Integrated Global Entertainment Leader Underpinned by our Content Catalogue and Deep_**
**_Portfolio of Intellectual Property Rights_**

We intend to continue pursuing various selective and value-enhancing strategic acquisitions, business
combinations and joint ventures intended to complement and/or expand our business, in line with our
overall growth plan. We expect such acquisitions, business combinations and joint ventures to allow
us to expand our geographic footprint and diversify into new genres and markets, while gaining
access to top local talent. Our platform is scalable and has a demonstrated ability to integrate large
groups and implement synergies within a short period of time following transformative operations,
such as the Banijay Zodiak Merger and the Endemol Shine Acquisition. We also intend to continue
leveraging our distribution subsidiary, Banijay Rights Limited, to expand and optimize our content
catalogue through our business combinations. We regularly evaluate M&A opportunities and apply a
disciplined approach, pursuing transactions that comply with our cost-payback and other strategic
selection criteria, seeking targets that are cash generative, additive to the platform and synergistic.
Furthermore, following the Balich Acquisition, we intend to leverage our history of successful
strategic acquisitions to seamlessly integrate Balich into the Group and implement synergies resulting
from the transaction. Moving forward, we plan to fully leverage our management team’s proven track
record of delivering on their budget and use our strong M&A capabilities to sustainably consolidate
our leadership as the world’s leading independent producer and distributor of content.

We plan to capitalize on our know-how as the world’s leading independent producer and distributor of
content to develop a dedicated entertainment business. We believe that our ambition to become an
integrated global leader in the production of live events will be supported by the Balich Acquisition,
pursuant to which we will gain access to Balich’s international network and existing expertise in
creating, producing and delivering live shows. Our German production company, Brainpool, will also
undergo a restructuring of its live events, agency and tour division under a new label focused on
comedy event and stand-up artists. We plan on leveraging our production and distribution network to
unlock synergy value in the entertainment space, which we believe remains largely unconsolidated
and has a business model similar to that upon which the Group was built. Moving forward, we will
apply the same strategies in our entertainment business as we have in the past in our production and
distribution business to build our offering, relying on a mix of organic growth, synergies with the
other divisions of the Group and various selective, value-enhancing acquisitions, business
combinations and joint ventures.

**_Act as a Sustainable and Responsible Player at the Corporate and Production Levels_**

We aim to create an environment where employees can perform to the best of their abilities in an
inclusive work culture. We will continue to build diverse, supportive and collaborative teams, while
ensuring equal opportunities for our workforce, including through the development of our global


-----

diversity and inclusion board and employee resource groups. We foster inclusion and promote
diversity both on- and off-screen through specialized partnerships to drive best practice and ensure
that we attract and retain talents who share our values and support our local communities. In addition
to our ongoing focus on diversity and inclusion, we plan to continue promoting and emphasizing
professional and ethical behavior in the workplace, while at the same time fostering a positive
physical and mental health environment through new initiatives guaranteeing the health and wellbeing of our employees, such as the training of mental health first-aiders and the inclusion of care
guidelines in all format bibles across all production companies. As part of our long-term growth plan,
we also intend to continue advocating a sustainability-led mindset to reduce our carbon footprint and
overall impact on the environment. We believe that our efforts towards becoming a carbon-neutral
producer are bolstered by our continued collaboration with specialist consultancy firms and local
industry-led initiatives such as 3Degrees and Ecoprod, as well as our active membership of the Albert
Consortium, which we use as a platform to incentivize the television and film production industry to
reduce its waste and carbon footprint.

amount of the Existing Senior Secured Notes and (ii) pay fees and expenses incurred in connection
with the Transactions. The estimated sources and uses of the proceeds from the Offering are set forth
in “Use of Proceeds.” The Offering and the application of the proceeds from the Offering as set forth
under “Use of Proceeds” are collectively referred to in this offering memorandum as the
“Transactions.”

**Our Principal Shareholders**

On July 1, 2022, the ordinary shares of our indirect parent company, FLE, were successfully admitted
to listing and trading on the Euronext Amsterdam regulated market under the symbol “FL
Entertainment” pursuant to FLE’s business combination with Pegasus. We set forth below
information regarding certain shareholders of FLE.

**_LOV Group_**

LOV Group was created in 2007 by Stéphane Courbit with the ambition to position itself at the heart
of growing markets such as audiovisual production, luxury hotels and online sports betting. LOV
Group currently operates in over 23 countries and is the main direct or indirect shareholder in almost
all of its subsidiaries, such as Betclic Everest Group, LOV Hotel Collection and Banijay. LOV
Group’s mission is to identify growing markets, develop new businesses as well as seek investments
in innovative and high growth potential companies. LOV Group provides its subsidiaries with human,
financial, legal and strategic support.

**_Vivendi_**

Vivendi is a global leader in culture, entertainment, media and communications. Vivendi operates
businesses throughout the media value chain, from talent discovery to the creation, production and
distribution of content. The main subsidiaries of Vivendi comprise Havas Group, Dailymotion, Canal
Plus and Vivendi Village. Through Havas Group, Vivendi possesses unique creative expertise to
make a meaningful difference to brands, businesses and people. The distribution platforms
Dailymotion and Canal Plus ensure a large distribution of content and talent. Through Vivendi
Village, Vivendi develops complementary activities in live performance and ticketing. Vivendi’s


-----

different businesses and their employees cohesively work together as an integrated group to generate
greater value.

**_SBM International_**

Founded over 150 years ago, SBM International is one of the leading players in the gambling and
casino business in Europe and leader in luxury tourism market in Monaco. SBM International has
exclusive casino rights in Monaco and owns and runs the Casino de Monte-Carlo and Casino Café de
Paris. In the hospitality industry, SBM International owns and runs prestigious luxury hotels and over
25 restaurants and bars, including Michelin-starred restaurants.

**_Fimalac_**

Fimalac, founded in 1991, is an investment company owned by Marc Ladreit de Lacharrière, which
operates in five business areas: private equity, digital media, entertainment, leisure activities and
hotels and real estate. Fimalac holds investments in Warburg Pincus and Webedia, and also manages a
real estate portfolio comprising over 60,000 square meters of assets.

**_DeA_**

Founded in 1901, DeA is a family-owned industrial and financial holding company. DeA has grown
into a global enterprise with a diversified portfolio spanning publishing, media and television,
universities and education, lotteries and gaming, and asset management. DeA’s aim is to continue to
grow, expanding its portfolio with new investments, while maintaining an international focus and a
leading position in the sectors in which DeA operates.

Principles and certain other contractual and legal limitations, and may be released under certain circumstances. The laws of certain
jurisdictions in which the Guarantors are organized limit the amount of obligations that may be guaranteed, or in respect of which
security interests may be provided as well as the enforceability of the Guarantees and the security securing the Notes and the
Guarantees. For more information on limitations to the validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the security interests in the
Collateral and the liability of the Guarantors and the security providers, see “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and
_Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_

(7) We entered into the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement on February 7, 2020 (as amended, supplemented, and/or amended
and restated from time to time, including on December 29, 2021 and April 25, 2023). The Senior Facilities established under the
Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement include (i) the EUR Term Loan B1 in an aggregate principal amount of €555.0 million
and the USD Term Loan B1 in an aggregate principal amount of $560.0 million, in each case drawn in April 2023, and (ii) the
Revolving Credit Facility in the amount of €170.0 million (equivalent) to finance the general corporate and ongoing working capital
needs of the Group, of which €20.0 million was drawn in August 2023. The Guarantors guarantee the obligations under the Senior
Facilities on a senior secured basis. See “Description of Other Indebtedness and Financing Arrangements—Senior Secured Credit
_Facilities Agreement.”_

###### RISK FACTORS 

_An investment in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. In addition to considering carefully, in light_
_of the circumstances and your individual investment objectives, the information contained elsewhere_
_in this offering memorandum, you should carefully consider the risks described below before_
_investing in the Notes. If any of the events described below actually occurs, our business, results of_
_operations, financial condition or prospects could be materially adversely affected and, accordingly,_
_the value and the trading price of the Notes may decline, resulting in a loss of all or part of any_
_investment in the Notes. The order in which the risk factors are presented does not necessarily reflect_
_the likelihood of their occurrence or the magnitude or significance of the individual risk factors._
_Furthermore, the risks and uncertainties described herein may not be the only ones that we face._
_Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us or that we currently consider to be_
_immaterial may also have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial_
_condition or prospects._

**Risks Related to Our Business**

**_We may not be able to retain key personnel or creative talents or to attract new creative talents._**

Our business and our success have depended and will continue to depend on our creative talents, our
management team and other key employees or partners, such as hosts, producers and local managers
in our production companies. These individuals possess unique skills that are critical to the creation
and production of new formats and programs as well as the operation of our business. The loss or an
extended interruption in the services of one or more of our hosts, producers, senior management or
other key employees could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or
financial condition. Additionally, a limited number of our contracts (including contracts relating to
certain of our most important programs or formats, including, for example, Don’t Forget the Lyrics!
and It’s Only TV) with broadcasters contain “key man” provisions that would allow the counterparties
to terminate agreements early or to take over the production of the programs in case of the departure
of a specific host or talent or key people, and any such departure may depend on factors beyond our
control.

Considerable expertise could be lost or access thereto gained by competitors in the event of the
departure of our creative talents. We aim to retain our key managers, hosts, producers and creative
talents through various incentive agreements, such as earn-outs or put option agreements, when we
have acquired a company from them, incentive plans based on their contribution to the success of the
production company, non-compete clauses and exclusivity clauses. However, due to intense
competition within the industry, there is a risk of losing creative talents or qualified employees to
competitors or being unable to find a sufficient number of appropriate new talents or employees. For
example, it may be difficult to replace programs with or produced by Cyril Hanouna or Nagui, two
popular television hosts in France, or Bear Grylls. If any famous host were to leave our production
companies, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial
condition. In addition, certain of our scripted programs may be dependent on the availability and
performances of certain actors, actresses, directors and other creative talents. If we cannot retain these
talents or if they cannot continue to work on our programs for any reason, it could have a material
adverse effect on the production and distribution revenues from such scripted programs.

In addition to retaining talents, our future success depends in significant part on our ability to attract
new managers and creative talents as well as contractors and skilled and distinguished freelancers.
Competition for highly qualified management executives and creative talents is fierce. We may
experience difficulties in attracting new personnel, we may not be able to hire the necessary personnel
to implement our business strategy or we may need to pay higher compensation for employees than
we currently expect. A shortage in the availability of qualified personnel and creative talents could
limit our ability to grow. We cannot assure you that we will succeed in attracting and retaining the
personnel we need to develop our business, which may have a material adverse effect on our business,
results of operations or financial condition.


-----

We also benefit from the investments and the expertise of Stéphane Courbit, our Chairman, since he
founded the Group in 2007. Mr. Courbit, who is involved in our development and business strategy, is
the founder and chairman of LOV Group. LOV Group controls FLE, which directly holds 100% of
the share capital of Banijay Group Holding, the parent company of Banijay. Additionally, a limited
number of Banijay’s key managers and creative talents have a right to terminate their agreements with
us in the event Mr. Courbit leaves Banijay. Therefore, the departure of Mr. Courbit or any of these
key managers and creative talents could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of
operations or financial condition.

**_Customers may request to obtain intellectual property rights to the formats we create and programs_**
**_we produce, which may have a negative impact on our revenues._**

Broadcasters have increasingly requested intellectual property rights to the formats and programs for
which they fully fund the production. This trend is particularly strong in the United States and, to a
lesser extent, in other markets, where broadcasters tend to impose a “producer for hire” approach (i.e.,
the producer is an independent contractor managing the production process, without any intellectual
property rights to the program) and where it has become increasingly difficult for producers to retain
any intellectual property rights or a share of revenues from future licensing or sale, even when the
producer has originally developed the format or the program. In the United States, producers may be
required to finance at least part of the program to ensure that they are able to retain intellectual
property rights to the format, which is contrary to the market standard of fully funded non-scripted
business. In Europe, broadcasters have also started to ask for a share of ownership of the formats or
programs when they fully fund the production, whereas in certain countries, such as the Nordic
Countries and Italy, according to market practice, broadcasters generally co-own the content. For
example, in markets such as Germany, where broadcasters traditionally fully fund the production of
programs, we may not be able to retain intellectual property rights over the formats such broadcasters
have ordered, as such rights would be required by the broadcasters as a condition to funding.

The trend towards a “producer for hire” approach is also the general approach of digital platforms
such as Apple TV, Amazon Prime Video, Netflix and Google (which operates Android TV), in the
United States, Europe and other markets such as India and Latin America, which generally require the
transfer of ownership over all rights to the formats and programs that they finance. Digital platforms
usually require exploitation rights worldwide and in perpetuity for the programs they own, and may
ask for very long license periods in many territories or may require unlimited runs to air programs
based on preexisting formats they do not own or control and which rights are retained by us. The
increased viewership by consumers and the correlating demand and spending by digital platforms may
lead the “producer for hire” approach to become more prominent with traditional broadcasters outside
of the United States, as digital platforms exercise a growing influence over our market practices.
Notably, broadcasters have become reluctant to share revenues generated by intellectual property
rights that they used to share in the past. For example, unlimited VOD rights are now considered to be
“primary rights” in many markets and are granted to broadcasters for the entire license period without
sharing any additional revenues with the producer. Broadcasters may also require extensive holdbacks
to ensure that certain formats will not be used in the market in which they operate for a certain period
of time, even after they stop to commission new programs, and may require that none of their local
competitors be allowed to capitalize on these formats. When we are not able to retain sufficient
ownership of the intellectual property rights of the formats we create and programs we produce, we
may lose control over our formats and programs and a portion of the distribution and secondary
revenues. For the year ended December 31, 2022, our distribution and secondary business represented
17% of our total revenues. Insofar as new production does not produce additional retained intellectual
rights that can be sold or licensed, there is a risk that this revenue stream may decrease, or
alternatively, if we are unable to produce localized versions of our formats because we do not control
of the underlying intellectual property rights, that we may need to purchase intellectual property
developed by third parties in order to maintain this revenue stream.


-----

While we strive to retain maximum intellectual property rights when negotiating with broadcasters,
we may not be able to do so and, if this trend further develops, it could have a material adverse effect
on our business, results of operations or financial condition.

**_Intellectual property infringements may have a material adverse effect on our business._**

Our ability to compete in our industry depends, in part, upon successfully protecting and retaining our
proprietary and intellectual property, especially with respect to formats, which are more difficult to
protect than rights to a program, because a program is a finished product that has already aired rather
than a formalized concept. We protect our intellectual property rights to our formats and programs
through available copyright and trademark laws. We then license and distribute these rights to
reputable companies in specific territories for limited durations. Despite these precautions, existing
copyright and trademark laws offer only limited practical protection for formats in certain
jurisdictions. Unlike patents or trademarks for which registration is required, copyright does not
require any registration and provides limited protection as it is more difficult to prove and protect,
especially for formats. Copyright infringement is particularly difficult to defend in many parts of the
world that lack effective copyright and technical protective measures to prove copyright, or that lack
effective means for enforcing such measures, including certain jurisdictions in which we operate in
Asia. In addition, intellectual property rights may not effectively protect the content we distribute
around the world through our distribution business. The interpretation of copyright, privacy and other
laws as applied to our content, and piracy detection and enforcement efforts, remain in flux.
Specifically, uncertainty regarding the legal treatment of intellectual property rights created through
or with the assistance of artificial intelligence may make it harder to protect any such intellectual
property rights, or may otherwise significantly reduce the value of any such intellectual property
rights. The failure to strengthen or the weakening of existing intellectual property laws could also
make it more difficult for us to adequately protect our intellectual property and negatively affect its
value.

It may also be possible for unauthorized third parties to copy our formats or portions of our formats
without entering into a format license agreement with us or to exploit our programs, or part of our
programs, without entering into a license agreement for one of our programs. Unauthorized
distribution of our formats or programs has an adverse effect on our business because it reduces the
revenues that we are able to receive from the legitimate sale and distribution of our formats or
programs. It undermines lawful distribution channels and inhibits our ability to recoup or profit from
the costs incurred in creating such works. Our failure to protect our intellectual property rights in a
meaningful manner or challenges to related contractual rights could also result in erosion of our local
brands. We incur significant costs in order to protect intellectual property rights to our formats, to
monitor copyright infringement and to engage legal proceedings when necessary, which may affect
our profitability, and we may not be successful in preventing harm to our business.

In addition, it is an inherent risk in our industry that people may claim to have developed a format
similar to, and/or own intellectual property rights with respect to our formats and programs, whether
or not such claims are frivolous. We may have to resort to litigation, arbitration or other legal
proceedings in order to enforce our intellectual property rights, protect our trade secrets, determine the
validity and scope of the proprietary rights of others or defend against claims of infringement or
invalidity. Any such litigation or arbitration proceedings could result in substantial costs, including
costs for obtaining rights or the loss of the opportunity to earn revenues from the intellectual property
that is the subject of such proceeding, and the resulting diversion of resources and management’s
attention could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial
condition.

**_The revenues generated by our programs depend on positive reception by audiences, which is_**
**_difficult to predict and impacted by various factors that we do not control._**

Our core business is the development and production of programs that we license to broadcasters and
to digital platforms. We generate revenues not only from producing and licensing these programs, but
also from further development of the program (such as producing future seasons) and from secondary


-----

revenues such as the distribution in other countries or the licensing of related intellectual property
rights. Therefore, revenues from a program, other than the initial license to a broadcaster or digital
platform, depend on a program’s audience and its good ratings, which are synonymous with the
success of a program. A significant portion of our revenue, for example, is dependent on the
continued success and relevance of MasterChef (which represented 6% of our total revenues for the
year ended December 31, 2022) and Big Brother (which represented 8% of our total revenues for the
year ended December 31, 2022). Any change in viewer behavior impacting the continued viability of
these formats globally may materially impact our revenue and profitability. Furthermore, once we
have produced a program for a broadcaster, its success can be impacted by certain factors that we do
not control. For example, broadcasters choose the time slot for the program, and digital platforms
decide on the visibility of a given program within the services they offer without reference to ratings.
If a program is scheduled at a time that cannot adequately reach its targeted audience, the program
may not be successful despite its potential. Our customers can also control the promotion and
marketing around the program, if any. If a program does not reach a sufficient audience or does not
receive satisfactory ratings, we may lose opportunities to generate secondary revenues and, for
scripted programs that we have partially financed, we may also be unable to recover distribution
advances made by our distribution subsidiary, Banijay Rights Limited. While we try to reduce our
exposure to any particular program’s success, our business may be negatively impacted if any of our
key programs are no longer successful.

In addition, we have no control over whether broadcasters or digital platforms decide to renew our
programs for additional seasons. When we produce daily or weekly programs, our agreements with
broadcasters usually run for the whole television season, typically from September to June, and are
generally renewed on that basis. If one of our customers were to decide to stop broadcasting a
program that generates significant revenues for us, this may have a material adverse effect on our
business, results of operations or financial condition. In addition, certain scripted programs require
high production costs and upfront investments. Our distribution subsidiary, Banijay Rights Limited,
will sometimes participate in these upfront investments, anticipating revenues from the distribution of
the scripted program in various countries. If broadcasters or digital platforms decide not to renew the
program after the first or second season, we may incur losses with respect to our upfront investments.
Broadcasters and digital platforms may also decide to modify their offering to target a different
audience and therefore cancel certain existing programs in favor of fresh programs. Decisions from
broadcasters to terminate or not to renew some of our programs are discretionary and may have a
material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.

**_Our revenues and results of operations may fluctuate from period to period, including due to_**
**_seasonality._**

Revenues and projections for any independent production company that produces original television
and digital content can be expected to fluctuate until the content is delivered and could fluctuate even
after the content has aired. As a result of the broadcasting schedules of television networks and the
fact that broadcasters typically premiere shows in the second half of the calendar year, we generally
report higher revenues in the fourth quarter of the calendar year. In addition, we typically recognize
revenues from the sale of a program to a broadcaster at the time of the program’s delivery, which
creates a mismatch between the revenues we actually receive in connection with such sale and the
revenues recognized in our financial statements. The following factors could impact our generation of
revenues from time to time:

- Broadcasters may decide to make changes to a program during the production process, which
may increase our production costs and cause delays in delivery or even postpone delivery to the
next calendar year. Such delays may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of
operations or financial condition.

- All broadcasters have a period of time during which they may reject or return our programs for
modifications (both for editorial and technical reasons), and until the expiration of such period
and the final approval of our content, we may not be able to recognize the expected revenues.


-----

- Our revenues depend significantly upon the appeal of our content to our customers, the timing
of the release of our programs and the commercial success of these programs, none of which can
be predicted with certainty. For example, if a broadcaster decides not to renew one of our
programs, it could materially impact our revenues compared to the previous period.

- Unanticipated delays in a program’s production can delay our distribution revenues since we are
unable to distribute a program until it has been finalized.

Accordingly, our revenues and results of operations may fluctuate from period to period. The results
of one period may not be representative of the results of any future period. Any quarterly fluctuations
that we report in the future may not match the expectations of market analysts and investors. This
could cause the value of our local brands to fluctuate, which could have a material adverse effect on
our business, results of operations or financial condition.

**_Inaccurately anticipating changes and trends in popular culture, media or technology, which_**
**_impact viewing habits, can negatively affect our business, results of operations or financial_**
**_condition._**

Trends in the television and digital content sector change quickly. We have responded and continue to
respond to such trends and developments by modifying, refreshing, extending and expanding our
programming and product offerings on an ongoing basis. However, the ultimate appeal and popularity
of content and products targeted to viewers can be volatile and we may not be able to anticipate and
react quickly enough to shifts in tastes and interests within our local markets. If we inaccurately
anticipate trends in popular culture and media, our current content may become less attractive to
audiences and the ratings of our current programs may decrease, which could lead to reduced demand
for our programs and formats from our customers. We may also lose existing broadcasting slots and
new opportunities. Even if we accurately anticipate new trends in the television and digital content
sector, we may incur significant costs in adjusting to these new trends. For example, scripted
programs are increasingly popular, especially with the development of digital platforms, but are also
significantly more expensive to produce than non-scripted programs, which have historically
represented the core of our business. Adapting our business model to such new expensive trends may
have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.

A change in viewer and consumer preferences could cause our programming and our local brands to
decline in popularity, particularly if our targeted audience loses interest in our highest rated or viewed
programs or our daily programs, and thus, on the most profitable content in our portfolio. For the year
ended December 31, 2022, our top 15 shows collectively contributed to 17% of our production
revenues, with none of our formats and programs individually contributing to more than 2% of our
production revenues during the same period. Changes in viewer preferences and habits could decrease
our revenues and jeopardize the renewal of our contracts with broadcasters, distributors and other
customers. Moreover, we may invest substantial amounts of resources in a program that is not
renewed after the first season and as a result, we will not be able to reach the level of revenues and/or
margins budgeted and benefit from our production expertise to increase margins for the following
seasons, such as Fear Factor in Belgium in 2022. If our programs do not achieve sufficient consumer
and audience acceptance or satisfactory ratings, they are not likely to be renewed, which could lead to
a decline in our revenues from television and digital content production, distribution and ancillary
rights or these revenues may fail to grow to the extent we anticipate when making investment
decisions and thereby could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or
financial condition.

Viewers may also object to the content we produce or distribute based on their religious, political or
ideological positions. This may apply, in particular, to live broadcasts and content that is graphic in
nature, politically oriented or targeted at a specific segment of the audience, including, for example,
those who speak a certain language. This may also be the case with respect to regional reproductions
of successful formats. While we try to cater to social, cultural, religious and political positions while
making adaptions, we may not always be successful in doing so. Viewers, interest groups, political
and religious parties or other organizations may assert legal claims against us, seek to ban the


-----

exhibition of our media content, protest against our programs and products or object in a variety of
other ways.

**_We are subject to reputational risks as a result of our production companies’ activities_**

In recent years, our production companies have been subject to scrutiny as to the well-being of the
participants in our non-scripted programs and our reality programs in particular, and the effect of such
programs on the wider public. Any of the foregoing may require us to expend substantial resources
and/or to discontinue certain offerings, which could harm our reputation and have a material adverse
effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition. For example, Cyril Hanouna, one
of Banijay’s key managers and a very popular television host in France, was accused of inappropriate
behavior on television in Banijay’s program _Touche pas à mon poste!_ and, on June 7, 2017, the
French content regulator (Conseil supérieur de l’audiovisuel or the “CSA”) banned C8, the
broadcaster of Touche pas à mon poste!, from airing any advertisements during the program as well as
15 minutes before and after each broadcast for a period of three weeks. In addition, in April 2019, the
CSA issued a warning to C8 pursuant to which Touche pas à mon poste! could be prohibited to air in
prime time or access prime time, which may negatively impact our revenues as it might become
difficult to negotiate with this broadcaster in the future. Similar decisions could have a negative
impact on our local brand image and on our revenues. In addition, during the shooting of Koh Lanta
(the French adaptation of Survivor) in May 2018, an incident between two participants led to the
cancellation of the show. In the entertainment industry, instances of sexual harassment, other forms of
harassment and bullying and inappropriate behavior are increasingly brought to light. Any actual or
perceived inappropriate behavior from our employees or cast members, whether or not in the course
of a production, could have a significant negative impact on our reputation and on the popularity of
our content or result in legal action against us, the cancellation of our production rights, any of which
could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.

**_Natural disasters, adverse weather conditions and other catastrophic natural or manmade_**
**_calamities, as well as epidemics or pandemics, could have a significant adverse impact on our_**
**_business._**

Our production business is vulnerable to damage or disruption from severe weather events, such as
rain, snow, wind, storms, hurricanes or other natural disasters, such as flooding, earthquakes, volcanic
eruptions, nuclear disasters or a combination thereof, as well as other events, such as fire or war,
which may negatively impact our business. If any such events were to directly damage, destroy or
disrupt the operation of our production activities, it could delay our production, completion and
distribution of formats and programs in a timely fashion or at all, or result in significant remedial
costs, any of which could negatively impact our business. The impact of any of the foregoing could
have a materially adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and
prospects.

Furthermore, the COVID-19 pandemic and the measures implemented to contain its spread and
address its impact have had significant direct and indirect effects on businesses and commerce
generally, including disruptions to supply chain, workforce, international travel, transactional activity,
facility operation and production. As a result of some of the measures taken by governments in the
early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic to mitigate its spread, we were unable to film any of our
programs in a number of countries in which we operate from March 2020 to May 2020, which
resulted in a significant number of production delays. Additionally, filming of certain programs was
also postponed after May 2020 as a result of travel restrictions and constraints in the casting of actors,
candidates and hosts for our formats and programs. Once filming and production resumed, we also
incurred additional production costs in order to ensure compliance with governmental guidelines
regarding social distancing, on-site testing, sanitation and hygiene. Although some of these costs were
covered by our customers, they were not included in our production fee calculations and therefore
decreased our margins. The extent and scope of restrictions on the conduct of business that may be
put in place to combat any future resurgence of the COVID-19 pandemic are uncertain. Although
there was no meaningful impact on our business or financial condition from the COVID-19 pandemic


-----

in the six months ended June 30, 2023, we cannot predict the impact that any future developments
relating to it may have on our business.

A resurgence or prolonged continuance of a public health crisis could have a material adverse effect,
including materially increased volatility in financial markets and significant worsening of the global,
European or U.S. macroeconomic outlooks. There are no comparable recent events in scale and
duration that provide us with guidance, and so we cannot currently estimate with any certainty, nor
can we provide any assurance as to whether and how the COVID-19 pandemic will have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations in the future. For further
discussion on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business, see “Management’s Discussion
_and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—_ _Factors Affecting Our Results of_
_Operations—General Economic Conditions in Our Markets.”_

**_We may need additional capital to fund our growing operations, especially for the production of_**
**_scripted programs. If we are not able to obtain sufficient capital, we may be forced to limit the_**
**_scope of our operations._**
