###### Overview

We operate in the global television and digital content industry, which has traditionally had a value
chain made up of five component groups: producers, distributors, broadcasters, channels and
platforms, each of which traditionally committed to addressing a single vertical within the market.
The production and distribution components have largely consolidated, with many broadcasters (such
as BBC Worldwide), major studios (such as Disney, Warner Bros., Discovery and NBC Universal)
and scaled studios (including independents, such as Banijay) having both production and distribution
in-house. There remain a large number of independent producers who tend to operate on a somewhat
smaller scale and usually do not have distribution capabilities.

Next in the value chain are broadcasters/channels, which may be public service broadcasters (such as
PBS in the United States, France Télévisions in France, ARD in Germany, ABC in Australia and the
BBC in the United Kingdom), commercial channels (such as ABC in the United States, ProSieben in
Germany and TF1 in France), thematic pay TV channels (such as Canal Plus Group in France and
HGTV in the United States) or premium pay TV channels (such as Sky in the United Kingdom, Canal
Plus in France, Movistar in Spain and HBO in the United States). Platforms are also an important part
of the global television value chain and may be cable (such as Virgin Media), satellite (such as Sky or
DIRECTV), internet protocol television “IPTV” (such as BT), digital terrestrial television “DTT”
(such as Freeview) or VOD. VOD platforms, which continue to drive change in our industry, may be
AVOD (such as Pluto TV), subscription-funded “SVOD” (including in-house SVOD players such as
Amazon Prime Video, Netflix and Hulu) or transactional “TVOD” (such as iTunes Store and Google
Play). Television viewing generally has two axes: traditional “linear” viewing, ordinarily on a TV set,
and OTT viewing on a TV set, computer or mobile device (including VOD viewing), with some
platforms, such as the BBC, offering both linear and VOD viewing options.

The proliferation of OTT platforms in recent years has led to a significant improvement in quality and
breadth of available content, and the subsequent implementation of various packages and tiers has
given viewers increased optionality in how they want to consume content. The market is saturated,
with both entertainment and technology platforms (such as Apple TV+ and Amazon Prime Video)
offering scaled services. The following graphics shows the global traditional TC and OTT video
projected market growth between 2018 and 2027:


-----

Source: Management consulting firm industry reports

Over its approximately 70-year history, the global television industry has grown consistently and is
currently in a period of significant transition and development. At its advent, television was a
relatively restricted local industry, with two to four broadcasters in most countries, public service
broadcasters dominating and highly regulated commercial networks. From the late 1970s, the industry
entered a period of liberalization in which pay TV channels emerged and expanded in an environment
of regulatory relaxation and economies that boosted demand for advertising. In the late 1980s,
satellite and cable offerings drove multi-channel offers in many markets, while premium sports and
movie programming also expanded. Beginning around 2000, the “content revolution” saw formatted
non-scripted content spread across the globe and develop into international brands, which was boosted
by technological improvements such as digital television and broadband acceleration. The present
period is characterized by another set of technological improvements and consumption shifts, with the
rapid expansion of OTT viewing as well as internet-based television content aimed at the global
market, the growth of the Asian and Latin American television markets and a shift in power along the
value chain in favor of content and direct-to-consumer offerings.

**Linear Television Market Outlook**

The linear television market has remained critical to media companies’ business models, but is
anticipated to decline significantly in the coming years as viewers pivot to OTT offerings. Media
players have resultingly accelerated content available on streaming platforms, including sports, news
and entertainment. For players that have both a linear and digital offering, streaming spend tends to
make up a greater portion of content budgets. This trend is expected to continue, with total spending
for each expected to be near equal by the middle of the decade, including sports spend. It is expected
that the ongoing shift of content to streaming platforms will have implications on pay TV subscribers.
OTT providers have historically shown a high correlation between their content spend and subscriber
growth. As content becomes increasingly digital, this may create a negative compounding effect on
linear subscribers, as well as increasing cost of service as the price of the bundle rises. Consumer
cord-cutting, in favor of streaming options, continues to accelerate. Decline across linear pay TV
began in the middle of the last decade and have since further accelerated and are expected to create
even more challenging conditions for linear television looking ahead.

**VOD Television Market Outlook**

As linear TV continues to decline, direct-to-consumer is the key driver of growth for the television
market. The number of VOD options available to consumers has multiplied during the decline of
linear TV. Growth in this market has increased competitive pressure and turned differentiation
amongst platforms into a determining factor for success. Players are now attempting to draw interest
through varying business models, niche services, sports offerings and exclusive content across the
landscape. Pricing pressure is constantly intensifying, requiring VOD players to invest to add value to
their services and retain users. Many players such as Netflix, Amazon and Apple have built their own
production studios to create original content for their platforms and differentiate themselves from
competitors. Most players have also adopted and combined multiple monetization approaches in order
to attract a wide range of subscribers. Players are expected to increasingly integrate advertising-based


-----

models to offer VOD at no cost or for a lower end-user price than possible from an SVOD or TVOD
model to generate additional revenues. In addition, in the current context of rising inflation and in
markets with price-sensitive customers, combined monetization strategies have been widely adopted
by operators.

The global VOD market has been growing at strong rates during the past three years and presents
significant growth potential. In 2022, the OTT video segment generated revenues of approximately
$88 billion. This segment is expected to increase at a CAGR of 6.7% from 2022 to 2026. The VOD
market experienced significant revenue growth during 2020 and 2021, driven by the COVID-19
pandemic outbreak, quarantine policies and new hybrid working models. The main growth drivers
have subsequently become the expansion of both high-speed internet connections and smart devices
and the continuous creation of original content. As the VOD market matures in developed regions,
such as North America and Europe, service penetration in other areas, such as Latin America, Africa,
and the Asia-Pacific region, will continue to boost the total addressable market for services.
Compelling new and original content is key to attracting SVOD subscribers in these markets.
Moreover, retaining subscribers month-to-month requires substantial investments. Locally produced
content is key to the attraction and retention of viewers, which has driven global players to spend both
on acquired titles, as well as on original commissions in a range of new markets.

**The Global Content Production Industry**

Content production revenues are projected to grow sustainably, underpinned by (i) OTT platforms
(particularly global SVOD players Netflix and Amazon Prime Video, and in recent years, tech giants
Amazon and Apple) that drive both supply and demand for content and increase levels of competition
as well as total investment, (ii) competitive pressure across the media landscape to increase or
maintain their levels of content investment in order to retain their audiences and (iii) the increasing
influence of Asian content markets, particularly as large importers of content from Europe and North
America.

- _Development and creation of new content: Content producers such as Banijay create and develop_
new program concepts, known as formats, for television broadcasters and digital platforms, such
as VOD platforms. Programs and formats may be either “non-scripted,” such as reality shows,
entertainment shows, game shows or talk shows, or “scripted,” such as comedies or dramas that
follow a written story and plot line. Content may either be produced by the producer who created
the program or format, or by a third party that acquires the rights to produce the content through a
licensing agreement for a specific program or format and a specific geography. Content has
traditionally been developed to cater to the viewer preferences of specific geographic markets but
is increasingly being developed for wider audiences on a global scale, driven by the content offer
of global VOD services.

- _Commissioning and sale of new content: Once a program or format has been developed, it is_
pitched to broadcasters and/or digital platforms. A pitch generally includes a detailed description
of the program or format or, in certain instances, a full “pilot” is prepared by the production
company, either at its own expense or with the financial support from the broadcaster or digital
platform. The sales process for a format also generally includes the preparation of detailed
production schedules and budgets for the broadcaster or digital platform to consider when
deciding whether or not to commission a program or format. A program or format may either be
originated (for example, a new program or format is commissioned by a broadcaster or digital
platform), or it may be acquired (for example, the rights to an existing format are licensed for
local adaptation by a broadcaster or digital platform).

- _Production and airing of new content: Once a broadcaster or digital platform has confirmed the_
commissioning or purchase of a program or format, the production process begins and programs
based on the format are put into production. Production processes vary significantly depending on
the type of format or program, but generally involve pre-filming preparatory work, filming,
content editing and preparation of the program for delivery to the broadcaster or digital platform.


-----

Scripted programs generally require a more cost- and time-intensive development and production
process, as compared with non-scripted programs. The commissioning broadcaster or digital
platform generally have no obligation to air a program after its delivery.

**The Global Content Distribution Industry**

Content distributors control the rights to the content developed as described above. Distributors enter
into license agreements with licensees (mainly broadcasters and digital platforms), whereby such
licensees may exercise certain rights to a given format or program, including the right to produce
and/or air a format or program for a certain period of time and for a predetermined number of runs in
a specific Territory.

Distribution of content allows production companies to increase their profits because costs associated
with managing and selling a content library are relatively low, as compared to production costs. As a
result, our industry has witnessed significant consolidation of production and distribution functions in
recent years. Certain producers have pursued a vertically-integrated strategy, owning their own
distribution business, as we do with our distribution companies. However, not all producers have their
own distribution business and, as such, will grant licenses to distribution companies to distribute their
formats or programs on their behalf, in exchange for a distribution commission. Historically, large
international production groups such as Fremantle have been focused on maintaining exclusive
intellectual property rights to their content catalogues within the Territories in which they operate: this
business model generates additional production value and distribution revenues from format fees paid
by broadcasters. The royalties generated by the distribution business (the fees distributors receive
from their licensees after deducting their commission) constitute important secondary revenues for the
owners of the intellectual property rights to the format or program.

As part of the commissioning and sale process, the broadcaster or digital platform may try to obtain
ownership of the intellectual property rights to the program and/or the format itself. The owner of the
intellectual property rights will generally control the future use of the program or format across
jurisdictions and will, as a result, benefit from additional revenues generated, for example by
exporting the format to additional markets and worldwide program sales. Depending on the market,
broadcasters may retain all or part of such rights in the program and/or format. Otherwise, production
companies, including Banijay, retain full intellectual property rights to the format and program. The
ability to capitalize on formats or programs in forms other than the initial licensing to broadcasters
and digital platforms varies from one format or program to another. The additional rights received by
a producer from the content it has produced are known as “secondary rights.” In some cases, the
producer has no secondary rights, and in other cases, it may only have the right to distribute the
content in certain media and Territories for a limited term, depending on the ownership of the format
and the agreement with the relevant broadcaster or digital platform. Additional rights, or “ancillary
rights,” related to a format or program may also be granted to licensees, such as for merchandising,
music rights, DVD sales, digital services and mobile applications. These ancillary rights can drive
further revenues.

**Key Market Drivers**

Companies that are in the television and digital content production and distribution industry have
historically operated a B2B business model, with broadcasters, channels and platforms as their
primary customers. As a result, the dynamics affecting the production and distribution markets were
for a long time closely tied to those that impacted the wider broadcasting and television industry.
However, due to the emergence of new content buyers (such as VOD platforms) and even some
vertically-integrated direct-to-consumer offerings (such as Netflix), this traditional approach is
changing. Traditional industry players are continuing to invest in original content (both scripted and
non-scripted) largely driven by the competitive nature of the OTT space, which places independent
content developers, producers and distributors such as Banijay in a favorable position. The key forces
that are currently driving the global television and digital content industry are technological shifts


-----

caused by the rise of OTT services, a rationalization and strategic deployment of content spend and
the focus on global markets as areas of high growth potential.

**_Tailwinds in OTT Viewership and Recalibration of the Industry_**

The key technological force that continues to drive the market is the rise of OTT services, on the back
of the “broadband revolution” of the early 2000s. OTT platforms’ market share continue to increase.
Their rise has transformed the industry and has forced industry players to adapt and adjust their
business models. The reach of OTT technology is significant and continues to grow, albeit at a slower
pace.

At the end of 2022, Netflix had approximately 231 million subscribers worldwide, while Amazon had
roughly 245 million subscribers to its “Prime” service, which includes its streaming video offering.
One significant trend in the space, which will help to fuel further subscriber growth, is the
introduction of ad-supported tiers. Netflix, Disney+ and Max have launched ad-funded tiers in the
past two years, creating cheaper service tiers in which a portion of revenue is supported through
advertising. Long-term, these can expand the user base for their services by reaching new audiences.
Given these tiers are cheaper than paying for ad-free options, consumers are more likely to be willing
to subscribe to multiple platforms. As ad-supported tiers are further rolled out globally, and niche
services with lower price points become more common, the number of services consumers are willing
to pay for may increase. Given India and China represent significant markets due to the size of their
respective populations and the smaller extent of DTC penetration, they may present room for
especially significant growth. Lower penetration of SVOD may also be the result of slower broadband
speed, lack of local content and late market entry of local players.

The OTT environment is dominated by global players Netflix, Disney and Warner Bros. There are
also a number of strong local players (most of whom are broadcaster-led) who tend to put more focus
on innovation and on local content and production in order to compete with global players. Excluding
spending on sports, NBC Universal (approximately $21 billion), Disney (approximately $20 billion),
Warner Bros. Discovery (approximately $18 billion) and Netflix (approximately $17 billion) spent the
highest amounts on content in 2022. This spend is relatively flat compared to 2021. The amount of
spending is still significant, though competitors tend to prioritize profitability and cash flow
generation. Original content is still prioritized and drives viewership, often at a large expense, and
half of Netflix’s content streaming in the United States is original.

In addition to their increasing consumer base, OTT have an outsized influence on the content market,
as trends that first manifest at the OTT-level, such as binge-watching of boxed set content, tend to
migrate to traditional platforms. For example, networks now look for global reach with brands such as
_Planet Earth._

**_Rationalization and Deployment of Content Spend_**

OTT services are driving changes to consumer behavior in terms of (i) viewing patterns and (ii)
demand for content.

_Viewing patterns show shift towards on-demand_

“Linear” viewing on a television set has largely been replaced by on demand viewing. On demand
viewing may take many forms, from time-shifted viewing on traditional broadcast television channels
to the various online and/or streaming VOD options.

_Platform strategies are changing how dollars are spent on content_

As a result of the shift towards online and on demand viewing, content supply is expected to
increasingly reflect the demands of OTT audiences, which are currently characterized by viewer
appetite for high-budget scripted content and more globalized viewer tastes. Content spend is


-----

expected to continue increasing, albeit at a slower pace, due to the continued investment by VOD
players, new sources of revenue from online offerings and innovation in content forms.

At present, viewer demand is still largely focused on high-budget scripted content, which is driving
the majority of spend. Quality is becoming more important to drive engagement and subscriber
growth, rather than quantity of releases. Global content spend, which saw double digit growth in 2021
and mid-single digit growth in 2022, is expected to grow by approximately 2% in 2023. This is
partially due to the general macroeconomic environment and inflation, which along with shifting
investor sentiment towards sustainable profitability, has forced streaming companies to be more
efficient and targeting with their spending. One way in which this is happening is through a reduction
in the number of scripted TV shows ordered by some of the biggest and most established players,
notably Netflix. On the other hand, newer such as Amazon and Apple, are increasing their scripted
original TV series orders as they attempt to scale their platforms. While orders slow down, there is
still strong demand for new releases, which could lead to an imbalance of demand and supply. Nonscripted content can help to fill the gap, given the cheaper cost to produce and shorter time needed.
Banijay has particular experience and strength in non-scripted content and demand continues to be
high for this type of materials, which are especially lucrative.

Source: Luminate Film & Variety, Variety Intelligence Platform Analysis

Content spend has been relatively resilient during downturns. During the dot-com crash in the early
2000s content spend continued to rise, even as advertising revenues fell, and during the 2008 financial
crisis, content spend remained stable in Western Europe, even as advertising revenues dropped
precipitously. At the end of 2023, global content spend is projected to increase to approximately $243
billion, with continued growth partially driven by Apple and Amazon’s continued expansion into the
industry.

Source: Ampere

**_Global Markets as an Area of High Growth Potential_**

As the SVOD markets of North America and Western Europe mature, winning new subscribers is
becoming a notable challenge. Compelling new and original content is key to attracting SVOD


-----

subscribers in these markets, but is expensive. Moreover, retaining subscribers signed up month-tomonth requires ongoing investment. There is more headroom for the global streaming market to grow
in less developed markets, especially in the Asia-Pacific region. Locally produced content is key to
attracting and retaining subscribers, which has driven global players to spend not just on acquired
titles but on original commissions in a range of new markets. Latin America is also a lucrative OTT
market. It currently trails most other regions in number of OTT users, but is expected to grow
significantly over the coming years. Brazil, Mexico and Argentina are key countries in the region.
Among others, the significant increase over time in the numbers of OTT users is the rising number of
local-language competitors in the region, even as international players such as Netflix have already
found success. In Mexico, TelevisaUnivision has Blue To Go Sports and PrendeTV, and in Brazil,
Globo TV has Globoplay. These services are helping to further acclimate the local population to the
OTT video.

**Our Key Markets**

Banijay operates across markets in 21 countries, including 14 countries in Europe (Belgium, France,
Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, the Nordic Countries, Poland, Portugal, Spain, Switzerland and the
United Kingdom), three countries in the Americas (Brazil, Mexico and the United States), three
countries in the Asia Pacific region (Australia, India and New Zealand) and one country in the rest of
the world (Israel). While we expect that most of our key markets will generally continue to expand in
the near future, growth may be slower than in previous years. The television industry is generally
highly sensitive to macroeconomic conditions, particularly in sectors that rely on advertising
revenues. Further, while the rise of OTT may challenge traditional broadcasters, channels and
platforms, we believe their growth represents an opportunity for content producers, especially for
players such as Banijay, because they drive content demand and represent a growing segment of
content consumers. Each of our key markets requires a tailored approach to produce and distribute
content successfully. In particular, the balance between traditional platforms and emerging OTT
services vary in popularity and penetration across our key markets.

**_France_**

In 2022, the main pay TV players in the French market were Orange, Bouygues Telecom, SFR and
Canal Plus (which acquired Orange’s film and pay TV assets in January 2023), while TF1 is the main
broadcaster, followed by France Télévisions and M6. Independent producers outnumber in-house
broadcast production companies and are very active in the television production sector. The high
number of independent producers in France is due in part to the fact that French law requires
broadcasters to dedicate at least 67% of their investments in audiovisual works to independent
production. The largest players in the French independent production sector, other than Banijay, are
Fremantle and Newen.

**_Nordic Countries (Denmark and Sweden)_**

The main pay TV players in Denmark are TDC and Boxer Denmark and in Sweden are Tele 2 and
Allente, while DR and TV 2 are the main broadcasters in Denmark and SVT and TV4 are the main
broadcasters in Sweden. The major independent production players in Denmark, other than Banijay,
are Fremantle, NICE Entertainment and Red Arrow Studios. The Swedish independent production
industry is dominated by local independent producer NICE Entertainment, who competes with
international production houses such as Banijay, Fremantle and ITV Studios.

**_United States_**

The United States is an important geographic market in terms of both production and consumption.
The primary commercial networks are CBS, NBC, ABC and Fox and the primary pay TV market is
fragmented, with many platforms (such as Charter, Comcast and AT&T) offering similar packages.
The major U.S. studios (including Disney, Netflix and Warner Bros. Discovery) dominate the
production sector, but the independent production sector remains fragmented.


-----

**_Italy_**

The broadcast market in Italy is consolidated, with three networks (RAI, Mediaset and La7)
dominating the market. The main pay TV players are Sky Italia, Mediaset and Telecom Italia. The
production industry in Italy has had success in altering global formats for an Italian audience and is
led by, other than Banijay, independent production players such as Fremantle.

**_United Kingdom_**

The United Kingdom is a leading geographic market for the creation and launch of formats because
broadcasters demonstrate a willingness to experiment with new ideas and the legal framework
protects producers’ rights to their programs. Competition in the United Kingdom is high among
network broadcasters, as the broadcast market is highly fragmented, with BBC One holding the
highest weekly reach of all TV channels (58%), followed by ITV1, BBC Two, Channel 4 and Channel
5. The main pay TV players are Sky, Virgin Media, BT and Talk Talk. The production industry in the
United Kingdom is made up of key independent production players such as Banijay, All3Media,
Avalon TV, Carnival Films, Fremantle and Left Bank.

**Competitive Landscape**

Competition in the television and digital content production and distribution sectors remains
fragmented: in many markets, a number of small, independent groups are important market
participants. We have observed in recent years a trend towards significant consolidation within our
industry, particularly through vertical consolidation and business combinations of market participants
with one another. We believe that this consolidation is driven, in part, by market players’ desire to
expand their content portfolios, thereby allowing them to further develop their capacity to
successfully distribute their formats and programs. For example, most leading production groups also
have established distribution businesses. This branch of activity allows them to market and sell their
content and formats internationally to broadcasters and digital platforms. We have been an active and
successful player in the consolidation of our industry and Banijay has been the only significant
producer and distributor with worldwide operations that has managed to remain independent, as the
majority of large European production houses are now controlled by established broadcasting groups.

We are the world’s leading independent producer and distributor of content based on revenues for the
year ended December 31, 2022 and in terms of hours of content as of June 30, 2023. Banijay
competes with other integrated production and distribution groups such as ITV Studios, Fremantle
and All3Media, as well as smaller independent production companies, such as Tinopolis. Certain
competitors, such as ITV Studios, have experienced significant growth through M&A activity in
recent years. This is a reflection of the overall consolidation trend in the industry.

There are four key types of players in the global content production and distribution industry: major
studios (such as Warner Bros. Discovery and Disney), in-house content divisions (such as ITV
Studios and BBC Worldwide), scaled studios (including independents such as Banijay) and smaller
independents (such as Hat Trick and Beta), with local players, although locally significant, having a
comparatively small global role.

- _Major studios:_ major studios, most of which are based in the U.S., such as Warner Bros.
Discovery and Disney, tend to produce high-quality and expensive scripted content. Although we
do produce scripted content and intend to focus more resources on scripted content in the future,
we do not typically directly compete with major studios for content production contracts. Major
studios tend to have integrated production and distribution businesses.

- _In-house content divisions:_ certain broadcasters, such as BBC or ITV in the United Kingdom,
maintain their own in-house production departments. Some players have large in-house
departments, which can handle all content needs, but smaller players are often forced to outsource


-----

their content production to third parties. Companies with in-house production capacities are
integrated, as both production and distribution is done in-house.

- _Scaled studios (including independents):_ scaled studios (including independents) are often
established through business combination transactions whereby independent producers in various
markets are combined into one international group. In order to succeed and maximize market
share, these groups typically maintain a presence in the United Kingdom and the United States in
light of these markets’ importance for the overall industry. Scaled studios (including
independents) are free to experiment with different content formats and pursue various production
avenues. They are well-known for producing non-scripted formats which are popular with
broadcasters as they tend to be low-risk opportunities as their production costs are significantly
lower than scripted content. Scaled studios (including independents), including Banijay, tend to
have integrated production and distribution businesses.

- _Smaller independents: independent companies are generally groups whose activities are limited to_
a specific domestic or specialist market. In general, small independents focus on a particular niche
area or may even specialize in a specific show format and are known for producing creative
content and are often on the cutting edge of innovation. Smaller independent companies include
Elephant in France, Hat Trick and Avalon in the United Kingdom and Ballandi in Italy and 7 y
Accion and Zebra TV in Spain. Smaller independents tend not to, but may, have integrated
production and distribution businesses.

The major players in the global content distribution industry are largely the same as in the global
content production industry, following the consolidation of many key producers with distributors in
recent years.

###### BUSINESS 

**Overview**

We are the world’s leading independent producer and distributor of content based on revenues for the
year ended December 31, 2022. We are also the world’s leading independent producer and distributor
of content in terms of hours of content as of June 30, 2023. We develop, produce and distribute
television formats and programs and digital content for a wide range of customers. We operate over
130 production companies across 21 countries and have a multi-genre catalogue boasting over
172,000 hours of content. We have produced successful, and at times, long-running scripted and nonscripted formats and programs, such as _Survivor, Temptation Island, Peaky Blinders, Big Brother,_
_MasterChef, Rogue Heroes, Hunted, Black Mirror, LEGO Masters, Deal or No Deal, Grantchester,_
_Don’t Forget The Lyrics!, Marie Antoinette, Fort Boyard, Versailles, Mr. Bean and_ _Good Karma_
_Hospital. Our broad brand portfolio and large creative platform position us to continue to nurture and_
drive new formats for broadcasters and digital platforms.

We generate revenues through (i) the production of formats and programs; (ii) the distribution of
formats and programs for which we hold and/or control intellectual property rights and are entitled to
revenues generated by such formats and programs and (iii) commercial activities related to our brands
and programs, such as merchandising, sponsorship, licensing, digital partnerships, music and live
events. We produce both scripted and non-scripted content across all genres, including reality,
entertainment and talk shows, game shows, factual entertainment, documentary, drama, animation (or
kids) and comedy. Non-scripted content includes titles that do not follow a written storyline (for
example, entertainment, game shows or reality) and generated the majority of our revenues for the
year ended December 31, 2022, while scripted content includes programs that follow a written
scenario, which mainly consists of drama and comedy.

We own intellectual property rights to a broad and diversified portfolio of formats and programs, and
we generated the majority of our production revenues from our owned intellectual property for the
year ended December 31, 2022. The programs we own and/or control were distributed and licensed,
through our subsidiary, Banijay Rights Limited, to approximately 1,050 licensees, including linear
broadcasters and digital platforms worldwide, and we sold our products into 249 territories, in each
case for the year ended December 31, 2022. We retain (either through full ownership or control
pursuant to long-term and exclusive distribution contracts with third-party producers) the intellectual
property rights to most of our formats and programs. Such intellectual property rights are assets that
we generally distribute internationally and from which we seek to generate secondary revenues, such
as licensing of exploitation rights to broadcasters and digital platforms and sales of finished tapes and
branded content, in each case to supplement our initial production revenues.

We employ creative talents across all territories in which we operate in order to develop original
formats and produce original television programs based on our analysis of trends in the industry and
the demands of our customers. Thanks to our significant scale and the scope of our business, we have
access to a wide variety of industry-leading talents worldwide and high-quality creative content. For
the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we generated €3,242 million of revenues, of which €2,676
million (or 83% of total revenues) were production revenues, €413 million (or 12% of total revenues)
were distribution revenues and €153 million (or 5% of total revenues) were secondary revenues. For
the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, our Run-Rate Revenues was €3,609 million, our Run-Rate
Adjusted EBITDA was €544 million and our Adjusted Free Cash Flow was €347 million.

**_Strong Track Record of Successfully Integrating Value Accretive Acquisitions_**

We have a history of successfully pursuing various selective and value-enhancing strategic
acquisitions, business combinations and joint ventures intended to complement and/or expand our
business. We regularly pursue value-accretive bolt-on acquisitions to acquire production companies
and/or intellectual property rights in the markets where we are present. Thanks to these acquisitions,
we are able to expand into new markets or genres in a particular market, access new talent, acquire
intellectual property rights of formats and programs developed by such companies and benefit from
the expertise of their creative talents or producers. Some of our most recent acquisitions and
significant investments include Beyond in Australia in December 2022, A Fábrica in Brazil in March
2023, Twenty Two Productions in the Netherlands in March 2023, as well as our joint venture with
LaLiga in Spain in June 2023. Further, in June 2023, we agreed to acquire a controlling stake in
Balich, an Italian live entertainment business in charge of creating, producing and delivering live
shows and experiences that engage live audiences worldwide, active in 20 countries, in line with our
strategy to expand our live event activities. The following timeline shows our bolt-on acquisitions

We also have a proven track record of successfully integrating large groups and implementing
synergies within a short period of time following transformative acquisitions. For example, in 2020,
the completion of the Endemol Shine Acquisition allowed us to become the leading independent
player in Europe with the highest number of scripted content launches in 2022, thereby gaining the

to the successful integration of Endemol Shine into the Group, we benefitted from structural

Acquisition), in the medium term).

We are also focused on pursuing strategic joint ventures, which allow us to be involved in the early

Kingdom and the United States, the most active markets for international scripted shows, including

successful joint ventures in Mexico, such as Endemol Shine Boomdog, which was formed in 2018 to

Thanks to our successful acquisition track-record, we have been able to grow our platform globally,

industry, our significant scale allows us to increase our leverage when negotiating with broadcasters
and SVOD platforms, diversify our portfolio by introducing new cross-selling opportunities, increase
our financial capacity to fund a large number of formats, offer more competitive production budgets
by leveraging on combined resources and attract and retain talent.

**_A Cash Generative and Resilient Business Model Supported by a Recurring Revenue Base, Strong_**
**_Financial Performance, Cash Flow Visibility and a Flexible Cost Structure_**

Our portfolio of long-standing “super brands,” such as Big Brother, MasterChef, Survivor and
Temptation Island, allows us to benefit from strong and long-term recurring revenues, with 43% of
our production revenues for the year ended December 31, 2022 derived from content that has been
running for at least five consecutive seasons, 30% from content that has been running for two to five
consecutive seasons, and only 28% from new launches. Certain of our production companies, such as
Banijay Production Media, Adventure Line Productions and Bunim/Murray Productions have
produced television content for more than 20 years, and we benefit from their long-standing
relationships with broadcasters and other customers. We believe that our ability to propose original
formats with a cost-efficient production process has increased customer loyalty. We have further
expanded our customer base and captured business opportunities associated with the rise of SVOD
providers by developing relationships with Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, Disney+, Discovery+,
HBO Max, Paramount+ and Peacock.

Over the last three years, we have achieved significant Adjusted EBITDA improvement, which has
grown from €262 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €482 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022. Following our recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, our Adjusted EBITDA
margin levels normalized to 15% for the year ended December 31, 2022, demonstrating resilience
against inflation thanks to our cost-plus pricing-based business model, which allows us to pass on a
significant amount of incremental costs to our customers. This is higher than the average EBITDA
margin over the last three years of the producers that we consider to be our main competitors. We
have also reduced our leverage and maintained strong cash generation, with Adjusted Free Cash Flow
ranging from €256 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €349 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022. Our average cash conversion ratio for the same period was 83.2%, due in 2020 to
the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our production, tax and social security payments, and in
2021 to a favorable working capital cut-off effect at the end of the year and the normalization of our
production activities after the COVID-19 pandemic.We intend to continue to implement our
acquisition schemes based on earn-outs and put options in order to limit our cash interest expense.

We believe we have a largely de-risked business model. Our revenue benefits from the longevity of
our returning formats, such as Survivor, Big Brother, _MasterChef and Deal or No Deal. The majority_
of our formats air for more than one season, which generates long-term revenue streams and


-----

significant visibility into our operating performance as we secure budgeted revenues through contracts
signed early in the production process, and some of our returning formats benefit from multi-season
deals with broadcasters and digital platforms. These formats continue to be successful, for instance
with the 24[th] season of _Big Brother being viewed for approximately 8.3 billion minutes across all_
platforms in two months, with particular success in the U.S., and Survivor airing 25 series across 24
territories. For the year ended December 31, 2022, 28% and 73% of the Group’s production revenues
were generated by new and returning programs, respectively (of which 43% had been running for at
least five consecutive seasons, and 30% for two to five consecutive seasons). As of June 30, 2023, we
had already secured at least 84% of our estimated revenues for the year ending December 31, 2023.
Our business model is also supported by a stable level of content spend, which has been resilient
during economic downturns, as compared to advertisement spend. We have retained our competitive
advantage despite increasing pressures on advertising revenues, thanks to our focus on less expensive
non-scripted content, performing “super brands” that are pillars of traditional broadcasters and costefficient production plans.

We only commence the production for a program once a broadcaster or digital platform has agreed to
pay for the production and acquisition of the rights for such program, and the production costs have
been fully funded. We use the services of a significant number of freelance production artists and
technicians, depending on the level of television production activity in which we are engaged. Such
freelancers allow us to benefit from a flexible cost structure pursuant to which we can adjust our cost
base to the seasonality of production activity throughout the year. We estimate that approximately
80% of our cost structure is flexible. In addition, we attract, retain and incentivize talents via longterm incentive plans which are generally contingent and calculated based on the performance of the
relevant format over a specified time period. Therefore, our production costs and a significant share of
our staff costs are based on our performance and activity levels and are variable in nature.

We operate an asset-light model with limited ongoing capital expenditure requirements (representing
1.8% of revenues, including investments in intellectual property rights, for the year ended December
31, 2022), and low working capital requirements. Non-scripted programs are generally less capitalintensive and more profitable than scripted programs because they have shorter production cycles and
their budgeted production costs are covered in full before production begins. We believe that our mix
of scripted and non-scripted content is generally appropriate for our operations. In the event that we
seek to increase the proportion of our revenues generated by scripted programs, we do not anticipate
having to invest significantly as we expect that third-party financing sources will largely incur the
required upfront investment costs and that we will benefit from our existing catalogue’s distribution
revenues. In addition, we continuously promote financial discipline to maximize cash generation and
monitor our leverage.

(realizing cost synergies of approximately €67 million within a period of 18 months, exceeding the

ended December 31, 2022, we successfully completed 15 bolt-on acquisition in ten different
countries. Unlike some of our competitors, the Group is led by industry experts who understand our
creative talents and local production managers. This common culture and vision between our
management team and our creative talents have allowed us to attract and retain successful managers,
employees and partners. Furthermore, we benefit from the full support of our shareholders, including
DeA and Vivendi, two groups with a history of investing in the distribution of content and


-----

broadcasters. LOV Group and Vivendi are industry experts who understand the television production
and distribution business and are focused on developing original content. While most of the largest
television content producers in the world are affiliated with an entertainment group or a distribution
network, we remain independent, which enables us to serve customers without the limitations faced
by controlled producers regarding, for example, the content, style and format of their production. Our
independence allows us to innovate, deliver original, differentiated programs, be platform agnostic
and work with and retain a large pool of creative talents. In addition, as a scaled independent
producer, we benefit from competitive advantages compared to the in-house departments of
broadcasters and U.S. studios in Europe, which favor European independent producers.

We believe we are positioned at the forefront of content production and distribution as a premier
home for the industry’s leading on- and off-screen talent, and pride ourselves upon our ability to
attract, grow and retain top creative talent, including creative talent, producers, screenwriters and
directors. We have a number of key initiatives in place in order to further promote workforce
retention. In connection with the acquisition of production companies in various jurisdictions, we
typically enter into earn-out or put option agreements with certain managers and creative talents of
these companies in order to incentivize them to continue to work with us following the completion of
the relevant acquisition. Our management has also implemented a long-term incentive plan to ensure
the commitment of local management teams by rewarding key personnel based on their respective
value creation. In addition, our corporate organization is designed to foster creative freedom,
collaborative entrepreneurialism and commercial acumen. As a responsible employer, we are aware of
the rapid changes in lifestyles and ways of living of our employees, particularly following the
COVID-19 pandemic, and we actively seek to contribute to the improvement of our employees’
quality of life to maintain long, successful and trusting relationships. We have chosen to improve our
employee experience through the implementation of selective remote-working policies to help reduce
commuting stress, free up time and stay competitive in the talent war. We have also committed to
building diverse, supportive and collaborative teams through the development of our global diversity
& inclusion board and employee resource groups.

**Our Strategies**

We intend to further strengthen our business by focusing on the following key strategic objectives.

**_Continue to Create Premium International Content and Secure Intellectual Property Rights_**

Our goal is to continue to focus on high premium formats and programs that can travel to other
territories and be easily distributed globally to broadcasters and digital platforms looking for new
content, such as _Survivor,_ _Big Brother,_ _MasterChef and_ _Deal or No Deal. Through our dedicated_
distribution subsidiary, Banijay Rights Limited, we intend to leverage our know-how on successfully
selling or licensing our catalogue, including to customers in markets where we do not produce
content. We also intend to increase the size of our program portfolio to reach new customers in
emerging markets, such as India, where we believe there is great potential for growth in terms of
viewers and where a program based on the same format can be produced for different territories in
different languages, which we have capacity to produce thanks to our local production labels. For the
year ended December 31, 2022, we generated 12% of our total revenues from our distribution
business. Formats that have already been developed and produced, together with existing programs,
can be distributed with comparatively high margins.

We intend to apply our strategy of incentivizing local managing directors to develop adaptable
formats in-house with an international appeal that can generate distribution and other secondary
revenues, together with our proven format-sharing practices. Some of our most anticipated upcoming
releases include _Totally Spies! and_ _Nevsu. In addition, we plan to further develop our relationships_
with third-party producers to secure productions outside our footprint and distribution rights of
premium content through Banijay Rights Limited. We focus on sourcing partnerships and deals that
generate positive returns and making selective investments to secure intellectual property rights from
producers that we believe can deliver new long-running formats. We target premium scripted content
in the English language, which can be easily distributed internationally and is well-suited to the


-----

catalogue of many OTT platforms, as well as formatted non-scripted content which can often be
adapted by our companies worldwide.

We believe that this strategy will allow us to capitalize on current market trends, with SVOD
platforms increasing their demand for non-scripted content, in addition to their traditional focus on
scripted content. We also plan to continue focusing on developing know-how in our different markets
in order to create traction for upcoming formats developed in another country.

**_Optimize Content and Catalogue Monetization on All Platforms Globally_**

In the United States, SVOD services have increased the value of our catalogue series and movies due
to increased viewership by consumers and the correlating demand and spending by digital platforms.
Although these investments are primarily made in the United States and in English-language content,
the European market is gaining an increasing amount of traction with U.S.-based streaming platforms,
which are expanding globally. We also benefit from a supportive regulatory environment in Europe
which helps balancing bargaining powers when negotiating with SVOD platforms, hence allowing for
multiple monetization channels.

As a global independent producer with a proven track record of producing and distributing longlasting and travelling content (through local versions of some of the world’s biggest titles, as well as
original territorial content in local languages), we believe we are well-positioned to capitalize on these
trends and to efficiently monetize our content across all platforms through our “360-degree” strategy.
We intend to continue developing best-in-class internal format-sharing practices and, due to our size
and decentralized organizational structure, we believe we can tailor our formats and programs to our
target customers more easily than other large production groups, thereby efficiently monetizing our
content and catalogue. In addition, our distribution business enables us to license our portfolio
globally, including in markets in which we do not currently maintain production operations, and
generate revenues with high margins due to the relatively limited costs incurred in managing our
existing formats and programs.

We intend to increase our secondary revenues by better monetizing our large catalogue of over
172,000 hours of content. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we generated 5% of our revenues
from our commercial activity, including secondary revenues. We aim to increase secondary revenues
by taking advantage of in-program digital technologies and other features, and also developing
sponsorships with on-air partners to integrate product placement in our programs and to supplement
broadcasters’ production budgets. The rapidly growing AVOD market represents new secondary
window exploitation opportunities for our content, and we believe we have already positioned
ourselves as a leader in the FAST space to seize such opportunities, thanks to the operation of our
own FAST channels (including Horizons: Powered By Banijay) syndicated on platforms such as Pluto
or Freevee. We are also increasing our presence on social media platforms such as Meta and TikTok
in order to reach online audiences and further monetize our catalogue through digitalization.

In addition, we focus on developing branded content and partnerships with brands to establish content
supplier agreements with key global broadcasters. We try to retain ancillary rights when negotiating
with broadcasters to be able to develop merchandizing, branded events and experiences and off-air
licenses, and exploit the full value chain of our intellectual property rights. For example, we have
entered into a brand licensing arrangement for Peaky Blinders in connection with the development of
a freemium mobile strategy game. We are also able to monetize content with low development costs
through digital platforms with live-streaming capabilities, and through the development of games
based on intellectual property rights which we retain in connection with our formats.

We have leveraged our know-how with in-house talents by creating talent agencies which generate
secondary revenues, having followed the model of the talent management agency managed by
Brainpool. Notably, Banijay Talent operates as a French “influencer” marketing company that helps
brands grow with bespoke influencing strategies, and has generated significant follower growth for
its customer brands and developed key relationships with a large number of influencers from the
television, fashion, beauty, luxury, entertainment and sport sectors. We intend to further emulate the


-----

commercial success of Banijay Talent across other countries where we operate to increase our
secondary revenues.

**_Continue to Attract and Retain the Best Talents_**

We rely on our management team to implement our growth strategies and our creative talents to
produce formats that address our customers’ needs. Attracting, cultivating and retaining talents has
been, and will remain, critical to our success. We plan to continue to attract and retain highly skilled
personnel, particularly for their creative talent. We intend to further strengthen our collaborative and
entrepreneurial culture by continuing to incentivize our local managers to foster the high flexibility,
independence and autonomy of each of our production companies. We also intend to continue to run
our long-term incentive plan to ensure the commitment of local management teams and focus on
further aligning our key personnel’s interests with the Group’s through a focus on value creation.
Similarly, we plan to maintain our Group-wide bonus scheme to incentivize creative talents
responsible for the creation and development of successful formats that are adapted in our key
markets and have generated a certain production value for the Group. Talent attraction and retention is
also bolstered by our talent management systems, which allow us to anticipate departures and plan for
successions in the event of any departures.

Our proven track record of establishing successful joint ventures is also a key part of our talent
acquisition and retention strategy, as joint ventures appeal to talents who would like to maintain their
independence but are interested in a strong partnership with us. Talents of our joint venture partners
benefit from our broad creative network, access to financing, information, contacts and, most
importantly, our catalogue of formats, major brands and distribution capacity. In addition, they may
be able to sell us their remaining shareholding once the business has developed successfully because,
if a joint venture is successful, we may acquire the remaining share capital in the production company
on pre-agreed financial terms while retaining the talents who partnered with us.

**_Consolidate our Leadership Through Selective M&A to Further Strengthen our Position as an_**
**_Integrated Global Entertainment Leader Underpinned by our Content Catalogue and Deep_**
**_Portfolio of Intellectual Property Rights_**

We intend to continue pursuing various selective and value-enhancing strategic acquisitions, business
combinations and joint ventures intended to complement and/or expand our business, in line with our
overall growth plan. We expect such acquisitions, business combinations and joint ventures to allow
us to expand our geographic footprint and diversify into new genres and markets, while gaining
access to top local talent. Our platform is scalable and has a demonstrated ability to integrate large
groups and implement synergies within a short period of time following transformative operations,
such as the Banijay Zodiak Merger and the Endemol Shine Acquisition. We also intend to continue
leveraging our distribution subsidiary, Banijay Rights Limited, to expand and optimize our content
catalogue through our business combinations. We regularly evaluate M&A opportunities and apply a
disciplined approach, pursuing transactions that comply with our cost-payback and other strategic
selection criteria, seeking targets that are cash generative, additive to the platform and synergistic.
Furthermore, following the Balich Acquisition, we intend to leverage our history of successful
strategic acquisitions to seamlessly integrate Balich into the Group and implement synergies resulting
from the transaction. Moving forward, we plan to fully leverage our management team’s proven track
record of delivering on their budget and use our strong M&A capabilities to sustainably consolidate
our leadership as the world’s leading independent producer and distributor of content.

We plan to capitalize on our know-how as the world’s leading independent producer and distributor of
content to develop a dedicated entertainment business. We believe that our ambition to become an
integrated global leader in the production of live events will be supported by the Balich Acquisition,
pursuant to which we will gain access to Balich’s international network and existing expertise in
creating, producing and delivering live shows. Our German production company, Brainpool, will also
undergo a restructuring of its live events, agency and tour division under a new label focused on
comedy event and stand-up artists. We plan on leveraging our production and distribution network to


-----

unlock synergy value in the entertainment space, which we believe remains largely unconsolidated
and has a business model similar to that upon which the Group was built. Moving forward, we will
apply the same strategies in our entertainment business as we have in the past in our production and
distribution business to build our offering, relying on a mix of organic growth, synergies with the
other divisions of the Group and various selective, value-enhancing acquisitions, business
combinations and joint ventures.

**_Act as a Sustainable and Responsible Player at the Corporate and Production Levels_**

We aim to create an environment where employees can perform to the best of their abilities in an
inclusive work culture. We will continue to build diverse, supportive and collaborative teams, while
ensuring equal opportunities for our workforce, including through the development of our global
diversity and inclusion board and employee resource groups. We foster inclusion and promote
diversity both on- and off-screen through specialized partnerships to drive best practice and ensure
that we attract and retain talents who share our values and support our local communities. In addition
to our ongoing focus on diversity and inclusion, we plan to continue promoting and emphasizing
professional and ethical behavior in the workplace, while at the same time fostering a positive
physical and mental health environment through new initiatives guaranteeing the health and wellbeing of our employees, such as the training of mental health first-aiders and the inclusion of care
guidelines in all format bibles across all production companies. As part of our long-term growth plan,
we also intend to continue advocating a sustainability-led mindset to reduce our carbon footprint and
overall impact on the environment. We believe that our efforts towards becoming a carbon-neutral
producer are bolstered by our continued collaboration with specialist consultancy firms and local
industry-led initiatives such as 3Degrees and Ecoprod, as well as our active membership of the Albert
Consortium, which we use as a platform to incentivize the television and film production industry to
reduce its waste and carbon footprint.

**History**

The Group was established in 2007 by a team of experienced professionals led by Stéphane Courbit,
the founder and former Chief Executive Officer of Endemol France. Mr. Courbit initially invested in
Banijay through his family holding company, LGI, and subsequently integrated other private investors
such as the Agnelli Family through Exor N.V., the Drago and Boroli families through DeA, Jean-Paul
Bize through AMS Industries and Bernard Arnault through Groupe Arnault S.E. The Group is
currently managed by Mr. Courbit, who serves as Chairman, and by Marco Bassetti, our Chief
Executive Officer.

Mr. Courbit created the Group in order to build a worldwide brand in the content production business,
mostly through acquisitions of key local television and digital content producers. We have acquired
several television production companies since our inception, attracting leading managers in the
television and entertainment industries, including through the completion of the Banijay Zodiak
Merger in 2016, and the Endemol Shine Acquisition in 2020. On July 1, 2022, the ordinary shares of
our indirect parent company, FLE, were successfully admitted to listing and trading on the Euronext
Amsterdam regulated market under the symbol “FL Entertainment” pursuant to FLE’s business
combination with Pegasus. Since 2018, we have also established several joint ventures in the United
Kingdom and the United States, the most active markets for international scripted shows.

**Our Operations**

We create and produce television formats, programs and digital content in 21 countries, and sell and
distribute such television formats, programs and digital content globally. We consider the operations
of all of our subsidiaries to be similar and thus classify our operations into the following two main
businesses:

- _Production Business: Our production business is focused on creating and developing original_
content (scripted and non-scripted) through our production companies based on our analysis of
trends in the industry and the needs of linear broadcasters, global streaming platforms such as


-----

Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, HBO Max and other digital platforms. We benefit from the
creativity and expertise of all our talents. These talents are necessary in order to maintain our
policy to exclusively adapt our format catalogue through the Group’s global footprint via our
local production companies in the markets where we are present. In addition, we also acquire
licenses for formats owned by third parties in order to produce and license program based on
such formats to a broadcaster or a digital platform.

- _Distribution and Secondary Business: We generate revenues from the international distribution_
and licensing of intellectual property rights and merchandizing of successful formats and
programs. Our distribution business consists of licensing and distributing our portfolio of
formats and programs owned and/or controlled by the Group to traditional television channels,
local producers and digital platforms. We operate our distribution business primarily through
our subsidiary in the United Kingdom, Banijay Rights Limited.

**_Production_**

We develop television programs both based on formats created in-house or by licensing formats from
third parties in order to meet the demands of linear broadcasters, global streaming platforms and other
digital platforms.

_Development of Formats_

The first step in our production process is to develop new concepts for television programming. Once
these concepts are developed and formalized, we refer to them as “formats” and maintain intellectual
property rights over such formats, when possible. A successful track record and creative reputation
are key to continuing to develop original formats. From time to time, we also license the right to
produce formats owned by third parties, rather than developed in-house by us, in order to address
popular consumer trends and the needs of broadcasters and digital platforms. We either continue to
develop these formats in-house or pitch them to broadcasters and digital platforms. We develop a
wide variety of formats in order to avoid exposure to a limited number of titles and to keep a
diversified portfolio of formats.

We classify our formats in two main genres: non-scripted and scripted. We have historically focused
on developing non-scripted formats, which benefit from lower production costs, a shorter
development period and more advantageous financing arrangements, because the broadcaster who
acquires rights in the non-scripted content typically funds the full production costs. Non-scripted
formats can generate significant secondary revenues because they can be licensed and produced in
several countries. For example, a game show or reality show can be adapted in many countries,
sometimes under different names but with an identical concept. For the year ended December 31,
2022, non-scripted content generated €2,134 million, or 80%, of our production revenues. On the
other hand, scripted formats require higher upfront development costs and often need to be coproduced by several parties. We have significantly expanded our scripted activity to meet our
customers’ and the market’s increasing demand for scripted content. We currently have companies
producing scripted programming in all 21 countries where we are present. Scripted programs can also
generate significant secondary revenues, especially if such programs are in English, because they have
more appeal be sold worldwide to broadcasters and to local or global digital platforms.


-----

We develop new formats in each of our geographic markets. Our local subsidiaries have their own
creative teams which work together with Creative Networks, our Group-level central content team.
Creative Networks facilitates the sharing of new and existing formats to local teams worldwide, keeps
such teams informed of market trends outside their own territories and supports the creation of
formats that address both local markets needs and global trends. If successful, these formats may be
licensed and used in different markets and via different platforms.

Non-scripted:

We develop original formats and programs in four principal non-scripted genres:

- _Entertainment and Talk Shows: Entertainment and talk shows mainly encompass entertainment_
formats and programs that are studio-based. We believe our most successful entertainment
programs include It’s Only TV!, MasterChef, All Together Now, Go, Beat the Star, Your Face
_Sounds Familiar, All Against 1, Fort Boyard, LEGO Masters, Blow up and Starstruck. For the_
year ended December 31, 2022, our entertainment content and talk shows generated €670
million in production revenues.

- _Reality: Reality includes television programs in which ordinary people are continuously filmed_
outside their usual environment, designed to be entertaining rather than informative. We believe
our most successful reality programs include _Big Brother, Big Brother VIP, The Challenge,_
_Paradise Hotel, Survivor, Temptation Island, Hunted, SAS Who Dares Wins, The Biggest Loser_
_Beauty and the Geek, Joe Millionaire and_ _Star Academy. For the year ended December 31,_
2022, our reality content programs generated €815 million in production revenues.

- _Factual Entertainment: Factual entertainment is a combination of factual/documentary and_
entertainment programs, focusing on social experiments and popular topics. We believe our
most successful factual entertainment programs include _The Secret Life of 4 Year Olds,_
_Location, Location, Location, Below Deck, Wife Swap, The Island, Ambulance, One Born Every_
_Minute, Home of the Year, Your Home Made Perfect and_ _How to Look Good Naked. For the_
year ended December 31, 2022, our factual entertainment content programs generated €372
million in production revenues.

- _Game Shows: Game shows are predominantly programs in which contestants compete for prizes_
during games of knowledge, physical challenges or by luck. We believe our most successful
game shows include Don’t Forget the Lyrics!, Limitless Win, Identity, Minute to Win It, Tipping
_Point, Deal or No Deal, Pointless, The Money Drop, The Wall and The Legacy. Game shows_
have significant potential for secondary format revenues because they are easily adaptable to
different local markets. For the year ended December 31, 2022, our game show content
programs generated €189 million in production revenues.
