interests can be granted to a party other than the creditor of the claim purported to be secured by such
security interests. For that reason, the Security Documents pursuant to which a security interest under
Dutch law will be granted use a parallel debt structure, whereby the Dutch subsidiaries, as separate
and independent obligations, undertake to pay to the Security Agent for the benefit of the holders of
the Notes offered hereby amounts equal to the amounts due by it to the holders of the notes. Such
parallel debt structure therefore creates a separate and independent claim of the Security Agent for the
benefit of the holders of the Notes offered hereby which can be secured by a security interest.
Consequently, the security interests are granted to the Security Agent for the benefit of the holders of
the Notes offered hereby in its own capacity as creditor acting in its own name pursuant to the parallel
debt, and not as a representative (vertegenwoordiger) of the creditors. It is expressly agreed in such a
parallel debt provision that the obligations of the debtor to the Security Agent for the benefit of the
holders of the Notes offered hereby shall be decreased to the extent that the corresponding principal
obligations to the creditors are reduced (and vice versa). However, such a parallel debt structure has
never been tested before a Dutch court and we cannot assure that it will mitigate or eliminate the risk
of unenforceability posed by Dutch law.

Under Dutch law, receipt of any payment made by any Dutch Guarantor under a guarantee or security
interest may be adversely affected by specific or general defenses available to debtors under Dutch
law in respect of the validity, binding effect and enforceability of such guarantee or security interest.
The validity and enforceability of a guarantee of, or a security interest granted by or in, any Dutch
Guarantors may also be successfully contested by any Dutch Guarantors (or their receiver in
bankruptcy) on the basis of an ultra vires claim, as further described below. The validity and
enforceability of the obligations of our Dutch subsidiaries under a guarantee or security interest may
also be successfully contested by any creditor, or by the subsidiaries’ respective receiver in
bankruptcy when the subsidiary is in bankruptcy proceedings, if such obligation is prejudicial to the
interests of any other creditor and the other requirements for voidable preference under the Dutch
Civil Code and Dutch Bankruptcy Act are met, as further described below. As a result, the value of
the guarantee and security interests provided by the Dutch Guarantors may be limited.

In the context of inquiry proceedings, a corporate resolution approving the issuance of a guarantee by
the Dutch company or a security to be provided by the Dutch company may be suspended or voided
by the Enterprise Chamber of the Court of Appeals in Amsterdam (Ondernemingskamer van het
_Gerechtshof Amsterdam) on the motion of,_ _inter alios, one or more holders of shares or depository_
receipts issued for shares in such company who, solely or jointly, represent at least one tenth of the
issued capital or who are entitled to an amount of in shares or depository receipts issued therefore
with a nominal value of €225,000 or such lesser amount as is provided by the articles of association
(statuten) of the relevant company, and persons who are authorized to do so by the articles of
association or under an agreement with such company. The right to file such motion is further vested
in an association of employees which has amongst its members person working for the enterprise and
which has at least two years full legal capacity, and, for reasons of public interest, the advocate
general at the Court of Appeals in Amsterdam. Likewise, the guarantee or security itself may be
upheld by the Enterprise Chamber, yet actual payment under it may be suspended or voided.

Pursuant to Dutch law, payment under a guarantee or a security document governed by Dutch law
may be withheld under doctrines of reasonableness and fairness (redelijkheid en billijkheid), force
majeure (niet _toerekenbare_ _tekortkoming)_ and unforeseen circumstances (onvoorziene
_omstandigheden) and other defenses afforded by Dutch law to obligors generally. Other general_
defenses include claims that a guarantee or security interest should be avoided because it was entered
into through undue influence (misbruik van omstandigheden), fraud (bedrog), duress (bedreiging) or
error (dwaling). Other impeding factors include rights of suspension (opschorting), a dissolution of a
contract (ontbinding) and set-off (verrekening). Furthermore, the courts of the Netherlands may
change the effects of a contractual obligation on the basis of abuse of authority (misbruik van
_bevoegdheid). Moreover, enforcement of guarantees or security interests may be capable of being_


-----

rescinded (vernietigd) as a result of lack of consensus ad idem (wilsgebreken) and the legal
consequences thereof.

Pursuant to Article 2:7 of the Dutch Civil Code (Burgerlijk Wetboek), any transaction entered into by
a legal entity may be nullified by the legal entity itself or its receiver in bankruptcy (curator) if the
objects of that entity as set out in the company’s articles of association (doeloverschrijding) were
transgressed by the transaction and the other party to the transaction knew or should have known this
without independent investigation (wist of zonder eigen onderzoek moest weten). The Dutch Supreme
Court (Hoge Raad der Nederlanden) has ruled that in determining whether the objects of a legal entity
are transgressed, not only the description of the objects in that legal entity’s articles of association
(statuten) is decisive, but all (relevant) circumstances must be taken into account, in particular
whether the transaction is in the company’s corporate interests (vennootschappelijk belang) and to its
benefit; and whether the subsistence of the company is jeopardized by the transaction.

**_Fraudulent conveyance_**

Dutch law contains specific provisions dealing with fraudulent conveyance both in and outside of
bankruptcy, the so called _actio pauliana provisions. The_ _actio pauliana offers creditors protection_
against a decrease in their means of recovery. A legal act performed by a person (including, without
limitations, an agreement pursuant to which it guarantees the performance of the obligations of a third
party and any other legal act having similar effect) can be challenged in or outside bankruptcy of the
relevant person and may be nullified by the receiver in bankruptcy in a bankruptcy of the relevant
person or by any of the creditors of the relevant person outside bankruptcy, if (i) the person performed
such acts without an obligation to do so (onverplicht), (ii) the creditor concerned or, in the case of the
person’s bankruptcy, any creditor, was prejudiced in its means of recovery as a consequence of the act
and (iii) at the time the act was performed both the person and the counterparty to the transaction
knew or should have known that one or more of its creditors (existing or future) would be prejudiced
in their means of recovery, unless the act was entered into for no consideration (om niet) in which
case such knowledge of the counterparty is not necessary for a successful challenge on the grounds of
fraudulent conveyance. In addition, in the case of a bankruptcy, the receiver in bankruptcy may
nullify the performance of any due and payable obligation (including (without limitation) an
obligation to provide security for any of its or a third party’s obligations) if (i) the payee (hij die
_betaling ontving) knew that a request for bankruptcy had been filed at the moment of payment or (ii)_
the performance of the obligation was the result of a consultation between the debtor and the payee
with a view to give preference to the latter over the debtor’s other creditors.

**United States**

Some of the Guarantors and Collateral providers are subject to or organized under the laws of the
United States or certain states thereof. Under U.S. federal bankruptcy laws or comparable provisions
of state fraudulent transfer laws, under certain circumstances:

- the issuance of the Guarantees and the grant of security in the Collateral by entities subject to or
organized under the laws of the United States or certain states thereof (each, a “U.S. Provider”)
could be avoided;

- claims in respect of such Guarantees, liens or obligations could be subordinated to some or all of
a U.S. Provider’s other debts and other liabilities;

- the right of the Security Agent to repossess and dispose of the Collateral of a U.S. Provider upon
an event of default under the Indenture governing the Notes is likely to be significantly impaired
if such U.S. Provider commenced U.S. bankruptcy proceedings before such repossession or
disposal occurs; and

- the holders of the Notes could be required to repay any amounts received in connection with
such Guarantee or Collateral.


-----

**_Federal and State Insolvency Proceedings_**

Certain U.S. Providers may have operations that would subject any one or more either to federal
bankruptcy laws under title 11 of the United States Code (the “U.S. Bankruptcy Code”) or any
applicable state law insolvency proceedings. Proceedings under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code vary and
provide a debtor with discretion in its pursuit of a liquidation or reorganization strategy. The U.S.
Bankruptcy Code provides a detailed statutory framework that, among others, contains terms or
provisions relating to: (a) the administration of a bankruptcy case, including the provision of
“adequate protection” to secured creditors, the automatic stay, terms for the use, sale or lease of
property, standards for obtaining credit and the treatment of executory contracts and leases; (b)
creditors and claims, including filing proofs of claim, priority and allowance of claims, rights of
creditors and subordination of claims; (c) provisions relating to the creation of the bankruptcy estate,
including the scope of property of the estate and turnover and avoidance actions; liquidation under
chapter 7 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code; reorganization under chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code;
and ancillary and cross-border insolvency cases under chapter 15 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code.

As a general matter, chapter 7 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code provides for the orderly liquidation of the
debtor’s assets by a trustee, and typically, a chapter 7 case results in the immediate shutdown of the
debtor’s business. Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code is available to debtors who seek to
rehabilitate their businesses and work out their obligations to creditors. Unlike in chapter 7, the debtor
in a chapter 11 case typically remains in control of its assets and continues to operate its business
during the course of the bankruptcy case. In addition, “liquidating” chapter 11 cases may be utilized
as an alternative to chapter 7 liquidations, especially where the conversion of a pending chapter 11
case to a case under chapter 7 might prove prohibitively expensive or in an instance when a debtor
expects to sell all or substantially all of its assets. Because bankruptcy proceedings tend to be factspecific and vary case-by-case and because U.S. bankruptcy courts are courts of equity with broad
discretionary powers, a detailed summary of all of the provisions of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code that
could impact the Notes, the Collateral or the Guarantees is not contained herein. Furthermore, the
common law applicable in bankruptcy proceedings may vary from jurisdiction to jurisdiction, and this
summary is not intended to cover the common law that may apply in any particular jurisdiction.

With respect to proceedings under any applicable state insolvency laws (for example, assignments for
the benefit of creditors, receiverships or other state liquidation mechanisms) and the application of
state laws in bankruptcy proceedings, the effects and customs of these proceedings are fact-specific,
vary from state to state and require an examination of both statutory and common law, the details of
which also are not described herein. To the extent more information is required, potential investors in
the Notes should consult an insolvency professional familiar with U.S. and the applicable state
insolvency laws.

**_Delay and Risks Associated in a Federal Bankruptcy Proceeding_**

If a bankruptcy proceeding were to be commenced under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code by or against any
U.S. Provider, it is likely that delays will occur in enforcing the Guarantees or Collateral granted by
the bankrupt U.S. Provider, because of specific provisions of such laws or by a court applying general
principles of equity. Aspects of federal bankruptcy laws or general principles of equity that could
result in the impairment of rights include, but are not limited to:

- the automatic stay;

- avoidance of preferential transfers by a trustee or debtor-in-possession;

- substantive consolidation of the assets and liabilities of multiple entities;

- limitations on collectability of unmatured interest or attorney fees;

- fraudulent transfer; and


-----

- forced restructuring of the debt issued by the bankrupt company, including reduction of
principal amounts and interest rates and extension of maturity dates, or the conversion of debt to
equity interests, other forms of consideration (such as interests in a trust), or potential discharge
of all obligations without significant recovery, over the creditors’ objections.

As an initial matter, the commencement of a case under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code operates as a stay,
applicable to all creditors, of most litigation against the debtor and efforts to collect prepetition
claims, enforce existing liens or impose most new liens. The stay applies to the debtor and its assets
globally. The purpose of the stay is to provide the chapter 11 debtor time to reorganize and the chapter
7 trustee protection under which to liquidate in an orderly fashion the debtor’s assets for the benefit of
creditors. The automatic stay is also intended to shield a debtor from the pressures of creditor
collection efforts. Among others, the automatic stay prohibits (a) all collection efforts by creditors, (b)
the enforcement of prepetition judgments against the debtor or property of the estate, (c) any act to
create, perfect or enforce a lien against property of the estate and (d) the set off of prepetition debts
owing to the debtor against debts owing by the debtor. The automatic stay ordinarily does not bar
suits against non-debtor guarantors or co-obligors, nor does it enjoin payment under a letter of credit
issued by a bank in favor of a creditor of the applicable debtor. Applicable federal bankruptcy laws
generally do not permit the payment or accrual of interest, costs and attorney’s fees for unsecured or
“undersecured” claims.

**_Fraudulent Transfer Issues_**

Under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code or comparable provisions of state fraudulent transfer laws, the
issuance of Guarantees or provisions of Collateral by any U.S. Providers could be avoided if, among
others, at the time the U.S. Providers issued the Guarantees or provided Collateral (as the case may
be), the applicable U.S. Provider (a) intended to hinder, delay or defraud any present or future
creditor; or (b) received less than reasonably equivalent value or fair consideration for the incurrence
of such indebtedness and, in the case of (b) either:

- was insolvent or rendered insolvent by reason of such incurrence;

- was engaged in a business or transaction for which the U.S. Provider’s remaining assets
constituted unreasonably small capital; or

- intended to incur, or believed that it would incur, debts beyond its ability to pay such debts as
they mature.

The measures of insolvency for purposes of the foregoing considerations will vary depending upon
the law applied in any proceeding with respect to the foregoing. Generally, however, a U.S. Provider
would be considered insolvent if:

- the sum of its debts, including contingent liabilities, was greater than all of its assets, at a fair
valuation;

- the present fair saleable value of its assets was less than the amount that would be required to
pay its probable liabilities on its existing debts, including contingent liabilities, as they become
absolute and mature; or

- it could not pay its debts as they become due.

However, there can be no assurance as to what standard a court may apply in making solvency
determinations, and different courts may reach different conclusions with regards to these issues. In
an evidentiary ruling in the In re W.R. Grace & Co. bankruptcy case, the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for
the District of Delaware held that under the Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act, whether a transferor is
rendered insolvent by a transfer depends on the actual liabilities of the transferor, and not what the
transferor knows about such liabilities at the time of the transfer. Therefore, under that court’s
analysis, liabilities that are unknown, or that are known to exist but whose magnitude is not fully


-----

appreciated at the time of the transfer, may be taken into account in the context of a future
determination of insolvency. If the principle articulated by that court is applied, it would make it very
difficult to know whether a transferor is solvent at the time of transfer, and would increase the risk
that a transfer may in the future be found to be a fraudulent transfer.

By their terms, the Guarantees of each U.S. Provider will limit the liability of each such guarantor to
the maximum amount it can pay without the Guarantee being deemed a fraudulent transfer. It is not
assured, however, that this limitation will protect such Guarantee from fraudulent transfer challenges
or, if it does, that the remaining amount due and collectible under the Guarantee would suffice, if
necessary, to pay the Notes in full when due. In a recent Florida bankruptcy case, this kind of
provision was found to be ineffective to protect the guarantees.

In addition to the avoidance power that may be exercised in a U.S. bankruptcy, claims in respect of
liens or obligations evidenced by the Guarantees or Collateral may, in certain circumstances, be
subordinated under the equitable subordination provisions of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code.

**_Preference Issues_**

Any future pledge of Collateral by a U.S. Provider might be avoidable by the pledgor (as debtor-inpossession) or by its trustee in bankruptcy if certain events or circumstances exist or occur, including,
among others, if the pledgor is insolvent at the time of the pledge, the pledge permits the pledgee to
receive a greater recovery than it would otherwise receive in a hypothetical liquidation under chapter
7 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code and a bankruptcy proceeding in respect of the pledgor is commenced
within 90 days following the pledge, or, in certain circumstances, a longer period.

**Italy**

**_Introduction_**

The insolvency laws of Italy may not be as favorable to investors’ interests as those of other
jurisdictions with which investors may be familiar. In Italy, courts play a central role in the insolvency
process. Moreover, in court procedures may be materially more complex and the enforcement of
security interests by creditors in Italy can be more time-consuming than in equivalent situations in
jurisdictions with which holders of the Notes may be familiar.

The following is a brief description of certain aspects of insolvency law in Italy, which does not
include special provisions applying to banks, insurance and other companies authorized to carry out
certain reserved activities nor does it provide a comprehensive description of insolvency laws
applicable to public companies.

Insolvency laws and regulations have been reviewed and significantly amended (the “2019 Reform”).
In particular, on October 11, 2017, the Italian Senate approved Law No. 155 dated October 19, 2017
pursuant to which it has authorized the government to carry out a substantial reform of Italian
insolvency laws, on the basis of the guidelines provided therein, also taking into account the
recommendation of the EU Commission of March 12, 2014 on business failure and insolvency, which
in turn formed the basis for the draft EU directive on preventive restructuring frameworks currently
under discussion. The main amendments include: (i) the elimination of the term “bankruptcy”
(fallimento) due to its negative connotation and its replacement with a reference to a judicial
liquidation, (ii) the introduction of a definition of state of crisis, (iii) the adoption of the same
procedural framework to access the different insolvency procedures provided by law, (iv) express
acknowledgement and adoption of the definition of debtor’s COMI as provided for in the Recast
Insolvency Regulation, (v) a new set of rules concerning group restructurings, (vi) restrictions to the
use of the composition with creditors (concordato preventivo) in order to favor going-concern
restructurings, (vii) a new preventive alert and mediation phase to avoid insolvency and (viii)
jurisdiction of specialized courts over proceedings involving large debtors.


-----

In particular, the Italian government approved on January 12, 2019 the Legislative Decree No. 14 of
January 12, 2019 implementing the guidelines contained in Law No. 155 dated October 19, 2017,
which enacts a new comprehensive legal framework in order to regulate, _inter alios, insolvency_
matters. The Legislative Decree No. 14 of January 12, 2019 was published in the Gazzetta Ufficiale
on February 14, 2019 no. 38—Suppl. Ordinario no. 6, and, except for minor changes in some
provisions of the Italian Civil Code, which entered into force on March 16, 2019, the new insolvency
code entered into force on July 15, 2022 in the text largely amended by Legislative Decree No. 83
dated June 17, 2022, which transposed the Legislative Decree No. 14 of January 12, 2019 (the “New
Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law”) and replaced the Italian Royal Decree No. 267. of March 16,
1942, as in force before (the “Old Italian Bankruptcy Law”).

**_Certain Italian Insolvency Laws_**

Leaving aside the 2019 Reform, the Old Italian Bankruptcy Law saw many reforms in the near past.
In particular, a significant reform has been approved by the Italian Government on June 23, 2015
through a law-decree containing urgent reforms applicable, inter alios, to the Old Italian Bankruptcy
Law (the “2015 Decree”). The 2015 Decree entered into force in June 2015 (the date of its publication
in the _Gazzetta Ufficiale) and has been converted into law by the Italian Law No. 132/2015 (“Law_
132”). Law 132 entered into force on August 21, 2015 (the date after its publication in the Gazzetta
_Ufficiale). Subsequent amendments have thereafter been implemented by means of the adoption of (a)_
the Law Decree No. 59 of May 3, 2016, converted into law by Italian Law No. 119 of June 30, 2016,
and (b) Italian Law No. 232 of December 11, 2016.

The primary aim of the Old Italian Bankruptcy Law used to be to liquidate the debtor’s assets for the
satisfaction of creditors’ claims (with the continuation of the assets as a going-concern (when
applicable) only if this would satisfy a creditor’s claim). These competing aims have often been
balanced by the sale of businesses as going concerns and ensuring that employees are transferred
along with the businesses being sold. However, the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law has
changed approach with a view to promoting rescue procedures rather than liquidation, focusing on the
continuity and survival of financially distressed businesses and enhancing pre-insolvency
restructuring options.

The New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law regulates situations of crisis or insolvency (as defined
pursuant to article 2 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law) of the debtor, whether consumer
or professional, or entrepreneur exercising, including not for profit, commercial, craft or agricultural
business, operating as an individual, legal person or other collective entity, group of enterprises or
public company, excluding the State and public entities. In particular, the following debt restructuring
and insolvency proceedings are available under Italian law for companies in a state of crisis and for
insolvent companies:

(a) consumers may be subject to:

(i) the consumer over-indebtedness procedure (ristrutturazione dei debiti del consumatore)
pursuant to article 67 (the “Over-Indebtedness Procedure”) of the New Italian Crisis and
Insolvency Law; and

(ii) controlled judicial liquidation (liquidazione controllata) pursuant to articles 268 and ff.
of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law (the “Controlled Liquidation”);

(b) sole traders and enterprises falling under the category of “small enterprises” may be subject
to:

(i) moratoria (convenzione di moratoria) pursuant to article 62 of the New Italian Crisis and
Insolvency Law (“Moratoria”);

(ii) minor composition with creditors (concordato minore) pursuant to articles 74 and ff. of
the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law (the “Minor Composition with Creditors”);


-----

(iii) the negotiated composition (composizione negoziata della crisi) pursuant to articles 12
and following of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law (“Negotiated
Restructuring”);

(iv) the Controlled Liquidation; and

(c) entrepreneurs (imprenditori) that meet the following requirements: (1) annual assets in excess
of Euro 300,000 for the three previous fiscal years or, since the business activity commenced
if for a shorter period; (2) gross income in excess of Euro 200,000 during the same time
frame; and (3) debts, whether matured or unmatured, in excess of Euro 500,000, may be
subject to:

(i) judicial liquidation (liquidazione giudiziale) in accordance with the provisions of articles
121 and following of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law (“Judicial
Liquidation”);

(ii) preventative composition with creditors (concordato preventivo) pursuant to articles 84
and following of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law (“Composition with
Creditors”);

(iii) out-of-court reorganization plans (piani attestati di risanamento) pursuant to Article 56
of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law (“Out-of-Court Reorganization Plans”);

(iv) homologated restructuring plans and agreement pursuant to articles 57 and ff. of the New
Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, which include the following out of court arrangements
subject to court homologation: (A) restructuring agreements (accordi di ristrutturazione
_dei debiti) (“Hybrid Debt Restructuring”), which may also have extended effects, and (B)_
Moratoria;

(v) homologated reorganization plan (piano di ristrutturazione omologato), pursuant to
articles 64-bis and ff. of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law (“Homologated
Restructuring”); and

###### (vi) negotiated nestructuring.

**_Restructuring Outside of a Judicial Process (Accordi Stragiudiziali)_**

Restructuring generally takes place through a formal judicial process because it is more favorable for
the debtor and because arrangements put in place as a result of an out-of-court restructuring (other
than the ones entered into in execution of one of the legal tools described below) are vulnerable to
being reviewed by a court in the event of a subsequent insolvency, and possibly challenged as
voidable transactions. However, in cases where a company is solvent, but facing financial difficulties,
it may be possible to enter into an out-of-court arrangement with its creditors, which may safeguard
the existence of the company.

**_Out-of-Court Reorganization Plans (Piani Attestati di Risanamento)_**

Out-of-court debt restructuring agreements are based on restructuring plans (piani di risanamento
_attestati)._ In particular, pursuant to article 56 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, an
entrepreneur, including non-commercial one, in a state of crisis or insolvency, may prepare a plan,
addressed to creditors, in order to restructure their indebtedness and to ensure the recovery of their
financial condition. The plan shall: (a) allow the company's debt exposure to be restructured and (b)
ensure the rebalancing of the company's financial situation, and its reasonableness shall be certified
by an expert. An independent expert appointed directly by the debtor must verify the feasibility of the
restructuring plan and the truthfulness of the business data provided by the company. There is no need
to obtain court approval to appoint the expert. The expert must possess certain specific professional
and independence requirements and qualifications and meet the requirements set forth by Article 2399
of the Italian _codice civile, approved by the Royal Decree No. 262 of March 16, 1942 (as_
subsequently amended and restated, the “Italian Civil Code”) and may be subject to liability in case of


-----

misrepresentation or false certification. The terms and conditions of these plans are freely negotiable.
Unlike Composition with Creditor and Hybrid Debt Restructuring agreements, out-of-court
reorganization plans do not offer the debtor any protection against enforcement proceedings and/or
precautionary actions of third-party creditors. The New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law provides
that, should these plans fail and the debtor be declared insolvent, payments, acts and/or activities
carried out as part of the implementation of a reorganization plan, subject to certain conditions (a) are
not subject to claw-back action, save in case of wilful misconduct or gross negligence of the expert or
the debtor of which the creditor was aware at the time of the performance of the act, payment or
granting of the security and, (b) are exempted from the potential application of certain criminal
sanctions. Neither ratification by the court nor publication in the Italian Companies’ Register are
needed (although publication in the Italian Companies’ Register is possible upon a debtor’s request
and would allow to certain tax benefits), and, therefore, the risk of bad publicity or disvalue
judgments are lower than in case of an in-court pre-insolvency agreement or a debt restructuring
agreement.

**_Hybrid Debt Restructuring Agreements with Creditors (Accordi di Ristrutturazione dei Debiti)_**

Pursuant to Article 57 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, the entrepreneur, including noncommercial enterprises, except for the small enterprises, who is in a state of crisis or insolvency,
could enter into a debt restructuring agreements with creditors (accordi di ristrutturazione dei debiti)
representing at least 60% of the outstanding company’s debts to be ratified by the court. However,
pursuant to Article 60 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, the 60 % requirement is reduced
by half if: (a) the debtor has not requested temporary protective measures; and (b) creditors that are
not party to the agreements are liquidated in a timely manner. An independent expert appointed by the
debtor must assess the truthfulness of the business and accounting data provided by the company and
declare that the agreement is feasible and, particularly, that it ensures that the debts of the nonparticipating creditors can be fully satisfied within a 120 day term from: (i) the date of ratification of
the agreement by the court, in the case of debts which are due and payable to the non-participating
creditors as of the date of the sanctioning (omologazione) of the debt restructuring agreement by the
court; or (ii) the date on which the relevant debts fall due, in case of receivables which are not yet due
and payable to the non-participating creditors as of the date of the sanctioning (omologazione) of the
debt restructuring agreement by the court. Only a debtor who is insolvent or in a state of crisis (i.e.,
facing financial distress which does not yet amount to insolvency) can initiate this process and request
the court’s sanctioning (omologazione) of a debt restructuring agreement entered into with its
creditors.

The agreement is published in the companies’ register and becomes effective as of the day of its
publication.

If requested, protective measures apply from the date of deposit of the petition for the homologation
of the Hybrid Debt Restructuring agreement, provided that protective measures can be requested also
during negotiations of the Hybrid Debt Restructuring agreement. In particular, if protective measures
are requested, from the day of publication, the creditors concerned may not acquire rights of preemption unless agreed with the debtor nor may they begin or continue executive and precautionary
actions on his assets or on the property and rights with which the business activity is exercised.
However, (i) creditors cannot unilaterally refuse to perform or terminate existing contracts only since
the Hybrid Debt Restructuring petition has been filed; and (ii) creditors in respect of which protective
measures apply cannot unilaterally refuse to perform or terminate existing essential contracts solely as
a consequence of the failure to pay in respect of pre-existing claims.

The New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law does not expressly provide for any indications concerning
the contents of the Hybrid Debt Restructuring agreement. The plan can therefore provide, inter alios,
either for the prosecution of the business by the debtor or by a third party, or the sale of the business
to a third party, and may contain refinancing agreements, moratoria, write offs and/or postponements
of claims. The Hybrid Debt Restructuring agreement may also contain a proposed tax settlement for
the partial or deferred payment of certain taxes.


-----

Pursuant to Article 61 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, the debtor may ask to extend the
effects of the Hybrid Debt Restructuring agreement to creditors that are not part of it (accordi di
_ristrutturazione ad efficacia estesa) (i.e._ the “Hybrid Debt Restructuring with Extended Effects”),
provided that, inter alios, (a) all creditors of the relevant classes were notified of the negotiations and
had the chance to participate in the negotiations¸ (b) the restructuring plan provides for the business
continuation (provided that this requirement does not apply to extensions of the Hybrid Debt
Restructuring agreement made to banks and financial intermediaries); (c) the participating creditors
hold at least 75% of the claims of the relevant class; and (d) the non-participating creditors are repaid
for an amount at least equal to what they would have obtained through liquidation. In any case, the
Hybrid Debt Restructuring with Extended Effects cannot impose on non-adhering creditors the
performance of new obligations, the granting or maintenance of the availability of credit lines and the
granting of new facilities. Non-adhering creditors can file an opposition starting from the date of the
notification of the negotiations.

**_Moratoria (Convenzione di Moratoria)_**

Pursuant to Article 62 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, an entrepreneur (including those
involved in non-commercial activities) and its creditors may enter into moratoria agreement
(convenzione di moratoria) in order to temporarily regulate the effects of the crisis by obtaining a
payments postponement, waiver of judicial proceedings or suspension of enforcement measures.
Moratoria is also effective towards non-participating creditors of the same class of the participating
creditors, provided that under no circumstances, as a result of the agreement, the non-adhering
creditors may be required to perform new services, grant credit lines, maintain existing credit lines or
disburse new financing. For the purpose of being approved and effective against non-participating
creditors:

(a) all creditors belonging to the same category shall have been informed of the negotiations and
had the chance to participate;

(b) the participating creditors shall represent at least 75% of all creditors belonging to the same
class;

(c) there is a real prospect that non-participating creditors to whom the effects of the agreement
are extended, may be satisfied as a result of the agreement to an extent not less than what they
would obtain from a Judicial Liquidation;

(d) an independent expert certifies the truthfulness of company data, the suitability of the
agreement and the fulfilment of the conditions referred to in letter (c).

Non-adhering creditors can file an opposition within 30 days from the notification of the Moratoria.

**_Homologated Restructuring (Piano di ristrutturazione soggetto a omologazione)_**

Pursuant to Articles 64-bis and ff. of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, the entrepreneur,
other than small enterprises, involved in commercial activities and in a state of crisis or insolvency,
may distribute for the satisfaction of its creditors, subject to their division into classes according to
homogeneous legal position and economic interests, the value generated by the plan by way of
derogation from Articles 2740 (which provides that the debtor shall be liable for the performance of
obligations with all his present and future assets) and 2741 (which provides that creditors have an
equal right to be satisfied on the debtor's assets, subject to legitimate causes of pre-emption) of the
Italian Civil Code and from the provisions governing the graduation of legitimate causes of preemption, provided that the proposal for the restructuring plan is approved by all the classes of
creditors.

For each class of creditors, the proposal is approved if a majority of the claims allowed to vote is
reached or, failing that, if two thirds of voting creditors have voted in favour, provided that creditors
holding at least half of the total claims of the class have voted. Creditors with a right of pre-emption


-----

do not vote if satisfied in cash and in full, within one hundred and eighty days from the approval,
provided that the relevant collateral remains in place until the liquidation of the assets made for the
purpose of completing the payment in their favour. If the conditions set forth above are not met, the
creditors with a right of pre-emption shall be entitled vote and any residual unsecured claim shall be
allocated to the relevant different class.

If a dissenting creditor objects to the economic convenience of the restructuring proposal, the court
can approve the Homologated Restructuring proposal if it ensures the satisfaction of the claim in an
amount at least equal to the one that would be paid in the Judicial Liquidation.

**_Negotiated Restructuring (Composizione negoziata della crisi)_**

The composizione negoziata della crisi is an out-of-court proceeding that can be pursued, through an
online platform, by commercial enterprises (imprenditore commerciale) and agricultural enterprises
(imprenditore agricolo), which are in a distressed situation with reference to their assets, their
business and/or their finance, such that it is likely that a crisis or insolvency will follow. No
Negotiated Restructuring can be commenced if a petition has been already filed for a Composition
with Creditors, a Hybrid Debt Restructuring, an Over-Indebtedness Procedure or a Judicial
Liquidation proceeding.

The Negotiated Restructuring can be commenced on a voluntary basis only, with the filing of a
petition for the appointment of a third party and independent expert (the “Expert”). If the Expert finds
that there are concrete chances of recovery (risanamento), he/she meets with the parties involved in
the entrepreneur’s recovery process and presents the possible strategies, scheduling periodic meetings.
During the negotiations, all the parties involved must act in good faith and with fairness, must
cooperate and are bound by confidentiality on the entrepreneur’s situation, on the actions carried out
or planned by the entrepreneur and on the information received during the negotiations. If the Expert
finds that there are not concrete chances of recovery (risanamento), after the meeting with the
entrepreneur or thereafter, he/she notifies the entrepreneur and the secretary general of the relevant
Chamber of Commerce, which provides for the dismissal of the entrepreneur’s petition. In case of
small enterprises, the appointment of the Expert can be requested irrespectively of the recovery
prospects of the Small Enterprise.

The Expert’s appointment is considered terminated if, after 180 calendar days from its appointment,
the parties have not agreed on a solution (that can also be proposed by the Expert) for overcoming the
entrepreneur’s distressed situation. However, the Expert’s appointment can continue for up to an
additional 180 days if (i) all the parties involved in the negotiations require so and the Expert agrees,
or (ii) the prosecution of the appointment is required by a petition filed by the entrepreneur with the
court. Furthermore, the entrepreneur can request, together with the petition for appointment of the
Expert or with a subsequent petition, the implementation of protective measures, which would involve
that from the date of publication of the relevant petition, pre-existing creditors cannot obtain preemption rights (diritti di prelazione) unless agreed upon by the entrepreneur and all enforcement and
interim actions are stayed, which may last from 30 days to 120 days, extendable to a maximum of 240
days.

From the date of publication of the petition requesting the application of the protective measures until
the date of conclusion of the negotiations or dismissal of the petition for appointment of the Expert,
the entrepreneur cannot be declared insolvent by the court. The creditors whose rights are affected by
the protective measures cannot unilaterally refuse to perform their obligations under the contracts in
place with the entrepreneur, nor terminate such contracts, nor anticipate their expiration date, nor
amend them with detrimental consequences for the entrepreneur, solely on the ground of the missed
payment of claims arisen prior to the publication of the petition requesting the application of the
protective measures.

If the entrepreneur applies for the protective measures, he must simultaneously file the same request
to the competent court, to allow a judge to check the said protective measures and to confirm them or,


-----

if necessary, to modify them. In the absence of this request, the protective measures will be
ineffective. Upon request of the entrepreneur or of one or more creditors, or upon report of the Expert,
the protective measures can be revoked, or their duration can be reduced, if they do not satisfy the
purpose of a positive finalization of the negotiations or appear to be disproportionate compared to the
prejudice caused to the creditors that file the relevant request. In the event of cancellation or
termination of the protective measures, the prohibition to acquire pre-emptive rights unless agreed
with the entrepreneur shall cease as from the cancellation or termination of the protective measures.

Pending the negotiations, the entrepreneur may carry out acts pertaining to ordinary activity, and,
upon written notice to the Expert, carry out acts pertaining to extraordinary activity or make payments
non-consistent with the negotiations nor with the perspectives of recovery, in such a way as to avoid
prejudicing the economic and financial sustainability of the business. Furthermore, if during the
negotiations, it appears that the entrepreneur is insolvent but there are real prospects of recovery, the
entrepreneur shall manage the enterprise in the best interests of the creditors.

If the Expert believes that a certain act causes prejudice to the creditors, to the negotiations or to the
perspectives of recovery, he/she reports it to the entrepreneur and to the enterprise’s control body. If,
notwithstanding the Expert’s report, the entrepreneur carries out the relevant act, the entrepreneur
gives immediate notice to the Expert, who may file his/her dissent for the registration in the
companies’ register.
The court, upon the entrepreneur’s request and to the extent that this is consistent with the
continuation of the business as a going concern and with the maximization of the creditors’ recovery,
may authorize:

- the entrepreneur or one or more companies belonging to the same group to incur new super-senior
indebtedness pursuant to Article 6 of New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law;

- the entrepreneur to incur new super-senior indebtedness via shareholders’ financing; and

- the entrepreneur to transfer its business, or certain business branches, without the effects provided
under Article 2560, Paragraph 2, of the Italian Civil Code. However, in such case it will be for the
court itself to identify the measures it considers appropriate, taking into account the requests of the
parties concerned, in order to protect the interests of all relevant parties involved.

The Negotiated Restructuring can terminate as follow:

A. in case of entrepreneurs other than small enterprises:

(i) in case of positive outcome:

(a) execution of an agreement between the entrepreneur and one or more creditors with the
effects set out in article 25-bis, paragraph 1, of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency
Law;

(b) execution of a Moratoria; and

(c) execution of Out-of-Court Restructuring agreement.

(ii) if, at the end of the negotiations no solution is found:

(a) draw up an Out-of-Court Restructuring agreement referred to in Article 56 of the New
Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law;

(b) apply for the ratification of a Hybrid Debt Restructuring agreement pursuant to
Articles 57, 60 and 61 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law;


-----

(c) file an application for simplified Composition with Creditors with liquidation purpose
referred to in Article 25-sexies of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law;

(d) access one of the crisis and insolvency regulation instruments governed by the New
Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law.

B. in case of small enterprises:

(i) in case of positive outcome:

(a) execution of an agreement between the entrepreneur and one or more creditors aimed at
the continuation of the business, without effects against third party creditors;

(b) execution of a Moratoria; and

(c) execution of an agreement between the entrepreneur and one or more creditors with the
effects set out in article 25-bis, paragraph 1, of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency
Law.

(ii) If, at the end of the negotiations no solution among those referred above is found:

(e) file for a Minor Composition with Creditors;

(f) file a petition for Controlled Liquidation;

(g) file an application for simplified Composition with Creditors with liquidation purpose
referred to in Article 25-sexies of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law;

(h) for agricultural enterprises only, file a petition for Hybrid Debt Restructuring.

Pursuant to Article 24 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, inter alios, the acts authorized
by the court pursuant to Article 22 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law shall remain
effective if any of the following is subsequently commenced: a ratified Hybrid Debt Restructuring
agreement, a ratified Composition with Creditors agreement, an Hybrid Debt Restructuring agreement
proposed pursuant to Article 64-bis of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency, the opening of a Judicial
Liquidation proceeding, a compulsory liquidation, an extraordinary administration or simplified
Composition with Creditors with liquidation purpose referred to in Article 25-sexies of the New
Italian Crisis and Insolvency.

The acts, payments and guarantees made by the entrepreneur in the period following the Expert's
acceptance of the assignment shall not be subject to claw-back referred to in Article 166, paragraph 2,
provided that they are consistent with the course and state of negotiations and the prospects of
reorganisation existing at the time they were made.

Article 25-sexies of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law also introduces a simplified courtsupervised pre-insolvency composition with creditors with liquidation purpose (concordato
_semplificato per la liquidazione del patrimonio). Specifically, if the Expert states in its final report_
that the negotiations did not have a positive outcome but have been conducted according to fairness
and in good faith, and that the other outcomes are not feasible, within 60 days following the
notification of the final report of the Expert, the entrepreneur may file a petition for admission to the
_concordato semplificato per la liquidazione del patrimonio_ together with the liquidation plan. The
entrepreneur applies for approval of the concordato semplificato per la liquidazione by means of an
appeal to the court of the place where the company has its centre of main interests. The application
shall be communicated to the public prosecutor and published by the clerk of the court in the
commercial register no later than the day following the date of filing in the registry. From the date of
such publication, the effects provided under Articles 6, 46, 94 and 96 of the New Italian Crisis and
Insolvency Law apply.


-----

The court issues a decree approval (omologazione) the concordato semplificato per la liquidazione del
_patrimonio when it finds that (i) the proceeding has been carried out in accordance with relevant laws_
and regulations and the adversarial principle among the parties (contraddittorio); (ii) the proposal is
compliant with preemption rights (cause di prelazione) and the liquidation plan is feasible; and (iii)
the proposal does not cause a prejudice to the creditors compared to what they would receive in case
of Judicial Liquidation of the entrepreneur and in any case ensures that each creditor receives a certain
recovery.

The parties may file an objection (opposizione) to the above-mentioned decree within 30 days after
having been notified of the same.

**_Composition with Creditors (Concordato Preventivo)_**

An entrepreneur which is insolvent or in a situation of crisis (i.e. financial distress which does not yet
amount to insolvency) and that has not been subject to the Judicial Liquidation proceeding, has the
option to make a composition proposal to its creditors, under court supervision, in order to compose
its overall indebtedness and/or reorganize its business, thereby avoiding a declaration of insolvency
and the initiation of Judicial Liquidation proceedings. Only the debtor company can initially file a
petition with the court for a concordato preventivo (together with, among others, a restructuring plan
and an independent expert report assessing the feasibility of the composition proposal and the
truthfulness of the business and accounting data provided by the company). Petitions may also be
filed “con riserva”, pursuant to which the debtor may request a deferral to formulate an application
for access to such procedure by attaching the documents required by law. The court may grant a 30 to
60 days deferral (extendable by a further 60 days if there are justified reasons) within which the
debtor must file the proposal for Composition with Creditors. The petition for concordato preventivo
is then published by the debtor in the company’s register. From the date of such publication to the
date on which the court sanctions the _concordato preventivo, all enforcement and interim relief_
actions by the creditors (whose debt became due before the sanctioning of the concordato preventivo
by the court) are stayed. However, pursuant to Article 54, paragraph 2, of the New Italian Crisis and
Insolvency Law, the protective measures only apply if expressly requested by and approved by the
Court. In addition, the debtor may ask to the court, also after the admission to the Composition with
Creditors with subsequent request, further temporary measures in order to prevent certain actions of
one or more creditors that could prejudice the successful outcome of the initiatives taken to regulate
the state of crisis or insolvency. In case of Composition with Creditors with business continuity
creditors cannot unilaterally refuse to perform or terminate (i) existing contracts only for the reason
that the Composition with Creditors proceeding petition has been filed or the procedure commenced,
and (ii) in respect of which protective measures apply, existing essential contracts solely as a
consequence of the failure to pay in respect of pre-existing claims. Furthermore, pursuant to Article
46, paragraph 5, of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, pre-existing creditors cannot acquire
pre-emption rights effective vis-à-vis competing creditors (unless authorized by the court) and judicial
mortgages registered within the ninety days preceding the date on which the petition for the
Composition with Creditors is published in the companies' register are ineffective against such preexisting creditors.

The Composition with Creditors may provide either for the continuation or the liquidation of the
business. The composition proposal, by way of example, may provide for: (a) the restructuring of
debts and the satisfaction of creditors in any manner; (b) the transfer to a third party who undertakes
the debts (assuntore) of the operations of the business involved in the proposed composition
agreement; (c) the division of creditors into classes; and (d) different treatments for creditors
belonging to different classes. The composition plan which provides for the liquidation of the business
requires that the following two conditions are met: (a) unsecured creditors shall be satisfied for at
least 20% of their claim amount; and (b) the proposal envisages the provision of additional resources,
increasing the debtor’s assets of at least 10%. In an arrangement with continuation of the business,
creditors are satisfied, at least in part, for the direct or indirect proceeds deriving from the
continuation of the activities, also taking into account the value of contract renewals.


-----

If the court determines that the composition proposal is admissible, it appoints a judge (giudice
_delegato) to supervise the procedure, appoints one or more judicial officers (commissari giudiziali)_
and calls a creditors’ meeting. Pursuant to Article 109 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law,
the composition plan must be approved, through a telematic voting procedure, by creditors
representing a majority of claims entitled to vote (including preferred or secured creditors regarding
those claims to which they have waived their right to security in relation to the procedure or that are
not to be satisfied pursuant to the recovery plan). Where different classes of creditors are formed, the
composition plan is approved if it is approved by a majority of the claims admitted to the vote of each
class (or, in in the hypothesis of Composition with Creditors with business continuity, if such
requirement is not met, with the favourable vote of at least 2/3 of the creditors representing at least
half of the claims) and the majority of the classes (or all classes in the hypothesis of Composition with
Creditors with business continuity). Creditors with a lien, pledge or mortgage, even if the collateral is
contested, whose payment in full is provided for in the composition proposal, shall not be entitled to
vote unless they waive their preference right in whole or in part. If creditors waive their preference
rights in whole or in part, they shall be treated in the same way as unsecured creditors for the part of
the claim not covered by the security. Creditors with a preferred right, whose claims will be satisfied
only in part on the basis of the composition proposal, shall be treated in the same way as unsecured
creditors for the residual part of their claim.

Pursuant to Article 90 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law those who represent at least 10%
of the claims against the debtor, may submit a different composition proposal (proposta concorrente)
and the related plan no later than thirty days prior to the initial date set for the creditors to vote on the
proposal filed by the debtor. The _proposta concorrente will be admissible only if the debtor’s_
composition proposal does not guarantee the payment of at least 30% of the unsecured receivables.
This percentage is reduced to 20% where the debtor has successfully entered into a Negotiated
Restructuring.

When more proposals have been filed, these are all presented to the creditors for their vote and the
approved proposal is the one that receives more votes. In case of tie, the debtor’s proposal prevails, or
if the tie is between creditors’ proposals, the one filed earlier prevails. In any case, if none of the
proposals is approved with the majority mentioned above, the proposal that has obtained more votes is
presented again for approval.

Article 111 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law provides that, if within the time limit set for
the conclusion of the voting operations, the required majorities are not reached, the designated judge
shall immediately address the court by asking for the opening of the Judicial Liquidation proceeding.
If, conversely, the composition plan is approved, the court must ratify the composition plan and
decide on possible objections raised by dissenting creditors.

During the implementation of the composition plan, the company is managed by the debtor under the
supervision of a judicial commissioner (commissario giudiziale) appointed by the court and of the
court. Pursuant to article 113 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law the procedure ends with
the judgment of ratification by the court. On the contrary, if the Composition with Creditors fails, the
court may declare the opening of the Judicial Liquidation proceeding.

In addition, pursuant to Article 96 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, the solvency set-off
rules envisaged under Article 155 apply also to the Composition with Creditors as of the date of
submission of the petition for the Composition with Creditors.

Moreover, under Article 97 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, the debtor may request the
competent court to be authorized to terminate outstanding agreements (contratti ancora ineseguiti o
_non compiutamente eseguiti), except for certain agreements which are excluded from the scope of the_
above provision (e.g., employment agreements (rapporti di lavoro subordinato), preliminary sale
agreements (contratti preliminari di vendita), real estate lease agreements (contratti di locazione di
_immobili), etc.). The request may be filed with the competent court at the time of the filing of the_
application for the concordato preventivo or to the judge (giudice delegato), if the application is made


-----

after admission to the procedure. Upon the debtor’s request, the pending agreements can also be
suspended for a period of time not exceeding the period stated by the competent court. In such
circumstances, the other party has the right to receive an indemnification equivalent to the damages
suffered for the non-fulfillment of the agreement. Such indemnification would be paid prior to and
outside of the admission to the composition.

**_Minor Composition with Creditors (Concordato Minore)_**

Pursuant to Article 74 and ff. of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, professionals, small
enterprises, agricultural entrepreneur, start innovative start-ups and any other debtor not subject to
Judicial Liquidation, excluding consumers, in a state of over-indebtedness, may formulate to their
creditors a proposal for a composition with creditors allowing the continuance of their business
activity. If the Minor Composition with Creditors does not allow for the business continuity, it may
only be proposed when it envisages the contribution of external resources that appreciably increase
the satisfaction of the creditors.

The proposal must be filed to the court through a crisis resolution body together with a report from the
crisis resolution body covering, among other things, the causes of indebtedness, the debtor's diligence
in assuming the obligations and the reasons for the inability to fulfil the obligations. The proposal for
a Minor Composition with Creditors can have any content, shall specifically indicate the timeframe
and modalities for overcoming the over-indebtedness status and may provide for the satisfaction, also
in part, of receivables in any form, as well as the possible division of creditors into classes. The
provisions governing the Composition with Creditors apply save as otherwise provided.

**_Over-Indebtedness Procedures (Ristrutturazione dei debiti del consumatore)_**

Articles 67 and ff. of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law envisage a debt restructuring
procedure for consumers who are in a state of over-indebtedness. Specifically, the consumer may
propose to its creditors a plan that specifically indicates timeframes and methods for overcoming the
over-indebtedness. A consumer is considered not eligible and, consequently, cannot have access to
such procedure if it: (a) has already obtained a debt relief in the previous five years or otherwise
twice; (b) has determined over-indebtedness through gross negligence, bad faith or fraud.

The proposal made by the consumer can have any content and may provide for the satisfaction, also in
part and differentiated, of claims in any form and must be accompanied by the list of: (a) all creditors,
with an indication of the amounts due and the pre-emption rights; (b) description of its assets; (c) the
acts of extraordinary administration performed in the last five years; (d) income tax returns for the last
three years; (e) the salaries, pensions, wages and all other income of the debtor and his household,
with an indication of what is necessary for the maintenance of his family. The proposal may also
provide for the restructuring of debts arising from loan agreements with assignment of one-fifth of
salary (contratti di cessione del quinto), severance pay or pension and from loans secured by pledges,
as well as the possibility to provide for the partial satisfaction of secured claims provided that the
payment is at least equal to what they would receive from the liquidation of the secured assets based
on their market value.

The application must be submitted to the court through a crisis resolution body (organo di
_composizione della crisi)_ with the latter's report attached, which must contain: (a) a statement of the
causes of indebtedness and the diligence employed by the debtor in assuming the obligations; (b) a
statement of the reasons for the debtor's inability to fulfil the obligations undertaken; (c) an
assessment of the completeness and reliability of the documentation filed in support of the
application; (d) an estimation of the costs of the proceedings.

According to Article 70 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, the court, if it deems the plan
admissible, shall order by decree the online publication in the appropriate area of the court or the
Ministry of Justice’s website and that all creditors be notified within thirty days. Within twenty days
after the notice, any creditor may submit comments. Upon request of the debtor, the court may order


-----

the prohibition of executive and interim relief actions on the debtor's assets and envisage other
protective measures until the conclusion of the proceedings.

The judge, having verified the legal admissibility and economic feasibility of the plan and resolved
any disputes, ratify the plan by judgment. When one of the creditors or any other interested party
disputes the appropriateness of the proposal, the court may likewise ratify the plan if it considers that
in any case the claim of the opponent can be satisfied by the execution of the plan to for an amount
not lower than what it would receive through the Controlled Liquidation. If the plan is not
homologated by the court, the judge may open, upon request of the debtor and where the conditions
are met, the proceeding for the Controlled Liquidation of the over-indebted.

**_Controlled Liquidation (Liquidazione Controllata)_**

Pursuant to Articles 268 and ff. of the of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, professionals,
small enterprises, agricultural entrepreneur, innovative start-ups, and any other debtor not subject to a
Judicial Liquidation proceeding, if in a state of over-indebtedness, may apply to the competent court
for the opening a Controlled Liquidation proceeding of their assets.

When the debtor is in a state of insolvency, the petition for Controlled Liquidation may be filed by a
creditor even while individual enforcement proceedings are pending, provided that no Controlled
Liquidation can be commenced in such case if the amount of unpaid debt is lower than Euro
50,000.00. In addition, when the application is made by a creditor against a debtor who is a physical
person, there shall be no opening of such proceeding if the crisis resolution body, at the request of the
debtor, certifies that it is not possible to acquire assets to be distributed to creditors even through the
exercise of judicial actions. The application may be filed also by the public prosecutor, but only if the
over-indebtedness concerns entrepreneurs.

The judge, having ascertained the absence of alternative applications for the Over-Indebtedness
Procedure or Minor Composition with Creditors, declares the procedure open and appoints the
designated judge and the liquidator. Pursuant to Article 271 of the of the New Italian Crisis and
Insolvency Law, if the application for a Controlled Liquidation proceeding is proposed by creditors or
by the public prosecutor and the debtor requests access to an alternative procedure, the court shall
grant to him a time limit for supplementing the application. During such period, the Controlled
Liquidation proceeding cannot be opened and the related application is declared unsuccessful when an
alternative procedure of settlement of the crisis of the over-indebted has been opened. If, the debtor
fails to supplement the application or the alternative settlement procedure is not opened or is declared
terminated, the court orders the opening of the Controlled Liquidation proceeding.

Upon opening of the Controlled Liquidation all individual actions of creditors are stayed (subject to
certain exemptions) and creditors shall concur in the same manner (save as for any preference rights)
on the assets of the debtor. Furthermore, the execution of certain contracts and/or transactions pending
as of the date of the declaration of the Controlled Liquidation are suspended until the receiver decides
whether to take them over.

**_Judicial Liquidation (Liquidazione Giudiziale)_**

A request to declare a debtor insolvent and to commence a judicial liquidation proceedings (
_liquidazione giudiziale) for the judicial liquidation of its assets shall be made by means of an appeal to_
the competent court that can be filed (within one year from the termination of the business activity, if
the insolvency arose before the termination, or within the following year) by the debtor, the
supervisory bodies and administrative authorities performing control and supervisory functions over
the company, any of its creditors and, in certain cases, the public prosecutor when a debtor is
insolvent. Insolvency, as defined under the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, occurs when a
debtor is no longer able to regularly meet its obligations with ordinary means as they come due.
Judicial Liquidation is declared by the competent insolvency court.


-----

Upon the commencement of judicial liquidation proceedings, amongst other things, subject to certain
exceptions, all actions of creditors are stayed and creditors must file claims within a defined period. In
particular:

- claims secured by a pledge or secured by a lien pursuant to Articles 2756 and 2761 of the Italian
Civil Code may be realised outside the Judicial Liquidation also during the proceedings, after
they have been admitted as preferred claims, together with interests and expenses. In order to be
authorised to sell the secured assets, the creditor shall apply to the designated judge, who, after
hearing the receiver (curatore) and the creditors' committee, shall establish by decree the time of
the sale and determine the procedures to be followed pursuant to Article 216 of the New Italian
Crisis and Insolvency Law. The designated judge may assign the assets to the creditor who has
made the request and shall provide for the valuation of the assets subject to the authorisation or
assignment order. If the proceeds of the sale, net of expenses, or, in the case of an assignment,
the appraised value is higher than the amount of the claim with pre-emption rights, the creditor
shall pay the excess to the liquidator. The designated judge, after hearing the creditors'
committee, if one has been appointed, may also authorise the receiver to take back the pledged
or preferential assets, paying the creditor, or to carry out the sale;

- the administration of the debtor and the management of its assets are transferred to the receiver
(curatore);

- continuation of business may be authorized by the court if an interruption would cause greater
damage to the company, but only if the continuation of the company’s business does not cause
damage to creditors;

- any act (including payments, pledges, and issuance of guarantees) made by the debtor after (and
in certain cases even before for a limited period of time) the commencement of the proceedings,
other than those made through the receiver, become ineffective against creditors;

- the execution of certain contracts and/or transactions pending as of the date of the declaration of
the judicial liquidation are suspended until the receiver decides whether to take them over.
Although the general rule is that the receiver is allowed to terminate contracts where some or all
of the obligations have not been performed, certain contracts are subject to specific rules
expressly provided for by the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law; and

- pursuant to Article 155 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, creditors have a special
right of legal set-off, providing that creditors have the right to set-off their debts owed to the
insolvent against their claims towards it, even if the latter are not yet matured at the time of the
declaration of insolvency. However, for the purpose of set-off, the creditors’ claims need to be
(i) unconditional and (ii) able to be promptly determined in their specific amount according to
clear and specific criteria.

Judicial Liquidation proceedings are carried out under the direction of the receiver and supervised
by a deputy judge (giudice delegato) and a creditors’ committee. The receiver is not a representative
of the creditors and is responsible for the management and liquidation of the assets of the debtor to
the satisfaction of creditors. The proceeds from the liquidation are distributed to the creditors whose
claims have been filed and approved by the court in accordance with statutory priority. The
liquidation of a debtor can take a considerable amount of time, particularly in cases where the
debtor’s assets include real property. The New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law provides for
priority of payment to certain preferential creditors, including employees, the Italian treasury, and
judicial and social authorities. Such priority of payment is provided under mandatory provisions of
law (as a consequence it is untested and it is unlikely that priority of payments such as those
commonly provided in intercreditor contractual arrangements would be recognized by an Italian
insolvency estate to the extent they are inconsistent with the priorities provided by law).


-----

- Judicial Liquidation composition with creditors (concordato). Judicial Liquidation proceedings
can terminate prior to liquidation through a composition proposal with creditors. The relevant
proposal can be filed, by one or more creditors or third parties, from the declaration of
insolvency. By contrast, the debtor or its subsidiaries are only permitted to file such proposal
after one year following such declaration, but within two years following the decree giving
effectiveness to the liabilities account (stato passivo). Secured creditors are not entitled to vote
on the proposal of _concordato, unless and to the extent they waive their security or the_
_concordato provides that they will not receive full satisfaction of the fair market value of their_
secured assets (such value being assessed by an independent expert), in which case they can
vote only in respect of the part of their debt affected by the proposal.

The proposal may provide for the division of creditors into classes (thereby proposing different
treatment among the classes), the restructuring of debts and the satisfaction of creditors’ claims
in any manner. The concordato proposal must be approved by the creditors’ committee and the
creditors holding the majority (by value) of claims (and, if classes are formed, also by a majority
(by value) of the claims in a majority of the classes). Final court ratification is also required.
After the confirmation, the court closes the Judicial Liquidation proceeding and the enforcement
phase of the composition with creditors begins.

- Statutory priorities. The statutory priority assigned to creditors under the Old Italian Bankruptcy
Law may be different from the priorities in the United States, the United Kingdom and certain
other EU jurisdictions. Neither the debtor nor the court can deviate from the rules of statutory
priority by proposing their own priorities of claims or by subordinating one claim to another
based on equitable subordination principles (as a consequence it must be noted that priority of
payments such as those commonly provided in intercreditor contractual arrangements may not
be enforceable against an Italian bankruptcy estate to the extent they are inconsistent with the
priorities provided by law). The rules of statutory priority apply irrespective of whether the
proceeds are derived from the sale of the entire bankrupt’s estate or part thereof, or from a single
asset.

Article 221 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law establishes that proceeds of
liquidation shall be allocated according to the following order: (i) for payments of “pre
deductible” claims (i.e., claims originated in the insolvency proceeding, such as costs related to
the procedure); (ii) for payment of claims which are privileged, such as claims of secured
creditors; (iii) for the payment of unsecured creditors’ claims; and (iv) for the payment of
deferred claims. Under Italian law, the highest priority claims (after the costs of the proceedings
are paid) are the claims of preferential creditors including, inter alios, a claim whose priority is
legally acquired (i.e., repayment of rescue or interim financing, mentioned above), the claims of
the Italian tax authorities and social security administrators, and claims for employee wages.
The remaining priority claims are those of “privileged” creditors (creditori privilegiati; a
priority in payment in most circumstances, but not exclusively, provided for by law),
mortgagees (creditori ipotecari), pledgees (creditori pignoratizi) and unsecured creditors
(crediti chirografari).

- Avoidance powers in insolvency. Similar to other jurisdictions, there are so-called “claw-back”
or avoidance provisions under Italian law that may give rise, _inter alios, to the revocation of_
payments or to the granting of security interests made by the debtor prior to the declaration of
judicial liquidation. The key avoidance provisions address transactions made below market
value, preferential transactions and transactions made with a view to defraud creditors. Clawback rules under Italian law are normally considered to be particularly favorable to the receiver
in judicial liquidation compared to the rules applicable in other jurisdictions.

In judicial liquidation proceedings, depending on the circumstances, the New Italian Crisis and
Insolvency Law provides for a claw-back period of up to either two years, one year or six months
in certain circumstances (please note that in the context of extraordinary administration
procedures—see below—in relation to certain transactions, the claw-back period can be extended


-----

to five and three years, respectively) and a two-year ineffectiveness period for certain other
transactions.

The New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law distinguishes between acts or transactions which are
ineffective by operation of law and acts or transactions which are voidable at the request of the
receiver/court commissioner, as detailed below:

- Acts ineffective by operation of law.

(i) Under Article 163 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, subject to certain
limited exception, all transactions entered into for no consideration are ineffective vis-`avis creditors if entered into by the debtor entity in the two-year period prior to the
insolvency declaration. Any asset subject to a transaction which is ineffective pursuant to
Article 163 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law becomes part of the judicial
liquidation estate by operation of law upon registration (trascrizione) of the declaration of
judicial liquidation, without need to wait the ineffectiveness of the transaction is
sanctioned by a court. Any interested person may challenge the registration before the
delegated judge for violation of law pursuant to Article 133 of the New Italian Crisis and
Insolvency Law; and

(ii) under Article 164 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law, payments of receivables
falling due on the day of the insolvency declaration or thereafter are deemed ineffective
vis-à-vis creditors, if made by the debtor within the two-year period prior to the
insolvency declaration.

- Acts that may be avoided at the receiver’s request.

(i) The following acts and transactions, if done or made during the period specified below,
may be clawed back (revocati) vis-a-vis the judicial liquidation as provided for by article
166 of the New Italian Crisis and Insolvency Law and be declared ineffective, unless the
non-insolvent party proves that it had no actual or constructive knowledge of the debtor’s
insolvency at the time the transaction was entered into:

‒ transactions for valuable consideration in which the obligations performed or
assumed by the debtor exceed by more than one-fourth the consideration received or
promised in return;

‒ payments of debts, due and payable, which were not made by the debtor in
cash or by other customary means of payment in the year prior to the
insolvency declaration;

‒ pledges and mortgages granted by the debtor in the year prior to the insolvency
declaration in order to secure pre-existing debts which not yet due at the time the new
security was granted; and

‒ pledges and mortgages granted by the debtor in the six months prior to the
insolvency declaration in order to secure pre-existing debts which had already fallen
due at the time the new security was granted.

(ii) The following acts and transactions, if made during the vulnerability period or such
other period specified below, may be clawed back (revocati) and declared ineffective
if the receiver proves that the other party knew that the debtor was insolvent at the
time of the act or transaction:

‒ the payments of debts that are immediately due and payable and any onerous
transactions entered into or made within six months prior to the insolvency
